cardio.title: Cardiovascular
cardio.description: Heart failure, rhythms, shock, vascular disorders

data.fact:
Systole = Maximal force.
Diastole = Lowest force.
data.alert: Cuff too small = False High.
data.q: What defines systolic blood pressure?
data.rationale: Systole represents the maximal force of blood exerted against the artery walls during contraction.

data.alert: Widening = ICP. Narrowing = Shock.
data.q: What does a widening pulse pressure indicate?
data.rationale: A widening pulse pressure (higher systolic, lower diastolic) is a classic sign of Increased ICP (Cushing's Triad).

data.fact:
Angina = Relieved by Rest/Nitro.
MI = NOT relieved.
data.alert: MI Pain: Crushing, radiating, nausea.
data.q: How do you distinguish Angina from MI?
data.rationale: The key diagnostic difference clinically is that Angina Pectoris is relieved by Nitroglycerin and rest, whereas MI pain is not.

data.alert: SE: Headache, Hypotension.
data.q: What is the most common side effect of Nitroglycerin?
data.rationale: Nitroglycerin causes massive vasodilation, leading to cerebral vasodilation (Headache) and systemic hypotension.

data.alert: Check Apical Pulse. Hold if <60.
data.q: What must be assessed before giving Digoxin?
data.rationale: Digoxin slows the heart rate; giving it to a bradycardic patient can cause life-threatening heart block.

data.fact:
Left Sided = Lungs (Crackles).
Right Sided = Body (Edema).
data.alert: Wt gain > 3lb/wk is bad.
data.q: What is a classic sign of Left-Sided Heart Failure?
data.rationale: Left-sided failure backs fluid up into the Lungs (Left = Lungs), causing crackles and dyspnea.

data.alert: Tx: Fluids, O2, Elevate legs.
data.q: What are the early signs of hypovolemic shock?
data.rationale: The body compensates for low volume by increasing Heart Rate and Respiratory Rate to maintain perfusion.

data.fact: Deflating cuff too slowly causes venous congestion.
data.alert: Result: False High reading.
data.q: If you deflate a cuff TOO SLOWLY, the reading will be:
data.rationale: Slow deflation allows venous congestion to build up, falsely increasing the resistance and the reading.

data.alert: Result: Increased Blood Pressure.
data.q: Vasoconstriction will _____ blood pressure.
data.rationale: Narrowing the vessels increases resistance, which directly increases blood pressure.

data.alert: Result: Decreased Blood Pressure.
data.q: Vasodilation will _____ blood pressure.
data.rationale: Widening the vessels decreases resistance, which lowers blood pressure.

data.fact: Shock causes a decrease in circulating volume.
data.alert: Result: Decreased Blood Pressure.
data.q: Shock will _____ blood pressure.
data.rationale: Loss of volume (hypovolemia) leads to a drop in pressure.

data.alert: Result: Widened Pulse Pressure (Cushings Triad).
data.q: Increased intracranial pressure will _____ the pulse pressure.
data.rationale: Cushing's reflex causes systolic BP to rise to overcome ICP, widening the pulse pressure.

data.fact: Chest pain caused by decreased blood supply to myocardium (ischemia).
data.alert: Pain is crushing, substernal, radiating.
data.q: What causes angina pectoris?
data.rationale: Angina is ischemic pain caused by a mismatch between oxygen supply and demand.

data.fact: Take 1 tab q 5 mins x 3. If no relief, call MD.
data.alert: Drug dilates coronary arteries, increasing O2 supply.
data.q: How many nitroglycerin tabs can you take before calling the doctor?
data.rationale: Standard protocol is one tab every 5 minutes up to 3 doses. If pain persists, it may be an MI.

data.alert: Storage: Keep dry/cool. Replace q6mo.
data.q: By what route do you take nitro?
data.rationale: Sublingual administration allows rapid absorption into the bloodstream, bypassing the liver.

data.fact: Dilates coronary arteries to increase O2 supply.
data.alert: Also: Reduces preload.
data.q: What is the action of nitro?
data.rationale: Nitro is a potent vasodilator, improving blood flow to the heart muscle.

data.alert: Precaution: Wear gloves!
data.q: What precaution must the nurse take when administering topical nitro paste?
data.rationale: The medication can be absorbed through the nurse's skin, causing a severe headache.

data.fact: Necrosis (death) of myocardial cells due to blockage.
data.alert: Symptoms: Crushing pain, nausea, diaphoresis, cold/clammy skin.
data.q: What is the #1 symptom of an MI?
a: Severe chest pain unrelieved by rest/nitro
data.rationale: Pain that does not go away with rest or nitro is the hallmark sign of infarction vs angina.

data.fact: Crushing, heavy, squeezing. Radiates to L arm/jaw.
data.alert: Duration: >30 minutes.
data.q: What words will the client use to describe the pain of an MI?
data.rationale: Ischemic cardiac pain is typically described as pressure or squeezing, not sharp/stabbing.

data.fact: Death occurs within one hour of symptom onset in 50% of pts.
data.alert: Priority: Early intervention.
data.q: Death due to MI occurs within ___ of symptom onset in 50% of all patients.
data.rationale: The first hour is the "Golden Hour" due to the high risk of fatal arrhythmias like V-Fib.

data.alert: MONA: Morphine, Oxygen, Nitro, Aspirin.
data.q: What pain medication is given for the pain of a MI?
data.rationale: Morphine reduces pain and anxiety, and also decreases preload (venous return), resting the heart.

data.alert: Drug: Plavix also anti-platelet.
data.q: What is the reason for giving post MI patients ASA?
data.rationale: Aspirin inhibits platelet clumping, preventing further occlusion of the coronary arteries.

data.alert: Most Common Arrhythmia: PVCs.
data.q: The 3 most common complications after MI are...
data.rationale: Arrhythmias (electrical), CHF (pump failure), and Shock (severe failure) are direct consequences of heart muscle death.

data.alert: Treatment: Lidocaine or Amiodarone.
data.q: What drug is used to treat PVCs after an MI?
data.rationale: Lidocaine suppresses ventricular irritability (PVCs) which can lead to V-Fib.

data.fact: CPK, LDH, SGOT. Troponin rises earliest (3 hrs).
data.alert: Post-MI: Permanent EKG change is ST wave changes.
data.q: Which cardiac enzyme rises earliest after an MI?
data.rationale: Troponin is highly specific to cardiac muscle and rises within 3 hours of injury.

data.fact: Pump failure. IV fluids do NOT help.
data.alert: Tx: Cardiac drugs (Vasopressors/Inotropes).
data.q: Will fluid resuscitation treat cardiogenic shock?
data.rationale: The pump is broken; adding fluid volume overloads it further. You need drugs to strengthen the pump.

data.alert: Skin: Cold, clammy.
data.q: Will the client with a MI be nauseated? Diaphoretic?
data.rationale: Pain and decreased cardiac output trigger the autonomic nervous system, causing sweating and nausea.

data.alert: Q waves: Pathologic Q waves indicate necrosis.
data.q: What is the permanent EKG change seen post MI?
data.rationale: ST elevation indicates acute injury; pathologic Q waves indicate permanent tissue death.

data.alert: Decompensation: When these fail.
data.q: When cardiac output fails, name three ways the heart will try to compensate.
data.rationale: The heart beats faster (tachycardia) and grows larger (hypertrophy/dilation) to try to pump more blood.

data.alert: Goal: Reduce preload/afterload, increase contractility.
data.q: Name the three groups of drugs used to treat CHF?
data.rationale: Diuretics remove fluid, Vasodilators open vessels, and Digoxin strengthens the beat.

data.alert: Apply: Before getting out of bed. Remove daily.
data.q: When during the day should TED hose be applied?
data.rationale: Apply before legs are dependent (standing) to prevent fluid from pooling.

data.alert: Risk: Dislodging clot (Embolism).
data.q: Should you massage the calves of the client with CHF?
data.rationale: Massaging can dislodge a DVT (deep vein thrombosis), sending it to the lungs (PE).

data.alert: Risk: Hypokalemia potentiates toxicity.
data.q: Name the four most common toxic effects of digitalis.
a: Constipation, Dry mouth, Urinary retention, Blurred vision
data.rationale: Early signs are GI (nausea), late signs are visual (haloes) and cardiac (arrhythmias).

data.alert: Report: Gain of 3 lbs in one week.
data.q: What daily measurement best indicates fluid retention?
data.rationale: Weight gain is the most sensitive and reliable indicator of fluid status.

data.alert: Monitor: K+ levels.
data.q: When the client is taking diuretics, what mineral is the CHF client most likely to lose?
data.rationale: Loop diuretics like Lasix waste potassium, leading to hypokalemia.

data.alert: Prevention: Ambulation. Treatment: Anticoagulants, Bed rest. Never: Massage leg.
data.q: The best way to prevent thrombophlebitis is:
data.rationale: Walking pumps the calf muscles, aiding venous return and preventing stasis.

data.alert: Sign: Intermittent Claudication. Cause: Smoking.
data.q: What is the primary cause of Buerger's Disease?
data.rationale: Buerger's disease (Thromboangiitis obliterans) is strongly associated with tobacco use.

data.alert: Fingers turn White-Blue-Red. Trigger: Cold/Stress.
data.q: What triggers a Raynaud's attack?
data.rationale: Cold causes vasoconstriction, triggering the arterial spasm in fingers/toes.

data.alert: Pulse absent. Leg cool/pale/hairless.
data.q: What does a leg with PAD look like?
data.rationale: Lack of arterial blood flow leads to cool skin, pallor, and loss of hair follicles.

data.fact: A-fib and A-flutter = thrombus formation risk. A-fib: irregularly irregular rhythm. A-flutter: sawtooth pattern.
data.alert: Tx: Anticoagulants (Coumadin/Heparin), Cardioversion.
data.q: A-fib increases the risk for which complication?
data.rationale: The irregular rhythm causes blood to pool in the atria, forming clots that can embolize to the brain (stroke).

data.fact: Post-cath: Flat (HOB ≤30°), affected leg straight 4-6 hrs, bed rest.
data.alert: Check: Puncture site for bleeding/hematoma. Check distal pulses.
data.q: After cardiac catheterization, the nurse should keep the patient in what position?
data.rationale: Keeping the leg straight and the patient flat prevents bleeding from the femoral artery puncture site.

data.fact: Coronary Artery Bypass Graft. Saphenous vein or internal mammary artery used to bypass blockage.
data.alert: Post-op: Monitor chest tubes, mediastinal drainage, cardiac rhythm.
data.q: Which vessel is commonly harvested for CABG surgery?
data.rationale: The saphenous vein from the leg is most commonly used as a bypass graft conduit.

data.fact: Percutaneous Transluminal Coronary Angioplasty. Balloon catheter opens blocked artery. Stent may be placed.
data.alert: Post: Same as cardiac cath care. Monitor for re-occlusion (chest pain).
data.q: What is the primary concern after PTCA?
data.rationale: The artery can re-occlude after balloon angioplasty, requiring monitoring for return of chest pain.

data.fact: Streptokinase, Tenecteplase (TNKase). Dissolve clots. Given within 6 hours of MI onset.
data.alert: Risk: Bleeding. Monitor for reperfusion arrhythmias.
data.q: Fibrinolytic therapy must be given within how many hours of MI onset?
data.rationale: Fibrinolytics are most effective within 6 hours of symptom onset to dissolve the coronary thrombus.

data.fact: Pericardial Friction Rub on auscultation. Sharp chest pain.
data.alert: Pain relieved by leaning forward. Complication of MI, infection, surgery.
data.q: What position relieves pericarditis pain?
data.rationale: Leaning forward reduces pressure on the inflamed pericardium, decreasing pain.

data.fact: Post Group A Beta-hemolytic Strep infection. Affects aortic and mitral valves.
data.alert: Signs: Erythema Marginatum rash, elevated ASO titer/ESR. Tx: Penicillin G prophylaxis.
data.q: Rheumatic fever is a complication of which infection?
data.rationale: Rheumatic fever is an autoimmune response following Group A Strep pharyngitis that attacks heart valves.

data.fact: Left-to-Right shunt (no cyanosis initially). VSD, ASD, PDA, Coarctation of Aorta, Aortic Stenosis.
data.alert: PDA closure: Indomethacin (Antiprostaglandin).
data.q: In acyanotic heart defects, blood flows in which direction?
data.rationale: Acyanotic defects shunt oxygenated blood Left-to-Right, so there is no mixing of deoxygenated blood into systemic circulation initially.

data.fact: 3 T's: Tetralogy of Fallot, Truncus Arteriosus, Transposition of Great Vessels. Right-to-Left shunt.
data.alert: Polycythemia common (body compensates for low O2).
data.q: Which are the 3 T's of Cyanotic Heart Disease?
data.rationale: The 3 T's (Tetralogy of Fallot, Truncus Arteriosus, Transposition) cause right-to-left shunting of deoxygenated blood.

data.fact: Tetralogy of Fallot hypoxic episodes. Components: Pulmonary Stenosis, VSD, Overriding Aorta, RV Hypertrophy.
data.alert: Relief: Squatting or knee-chest position (traps blood in legs, increases SVR).
data.q: What position relieves a TET spell in a child with Tetralogy of Fallot?
data.rationale: Knee-chest position increases systemic vascular resistance, forcing more blood through the lungs.

data.fact: OK when patient can climb 2 flights of stairs without exertion.
data.alert: Take nitroglycerin prophylactically before sexual activity.
data.q: When can a post-MI patient safely resume sexual activity?
a: When able to climb 2 flights of stairs
data.rationale: Climbing 2 flights of stairs without chest pain or dyspnea indicates sufficient cardiac tolerance for sexual activity.

data.fact: Troponin (1 hr), CKMB (2-4 hr), Myoglobin (1-4 hr), LDH1 (12-24 hr).
data.alert: Troponin is most specific to cardiac muscle.
data.q: Which cardiac marker rises earliest and is most specific for MI?
data.rationale: Troponin rises within 1 hour and is highly specific to cardiac muscle damage, making it the gold standard.

data.fact: CCBs are "valium for the heart." They have Negative inotropic (weaker contractions), Negative chronotropic (slower rate), and Negative dromotropic (slower conduction) effects. They RELAX and SLOW the heart.
data.alert: If heart is fast, tachyrhythmic, or in heart block — needs to be rested — GIVE CCB. If you are in heart block, you are in heart block — do NOT stimulate. Nurse should assess HR and BP before giving CCBs.
data.q: Calcium channel blockers produce which effect on the heart?
data.rationale: CCBs have negative inotropic, chronotropic, and dromotropic effects — they slow the heart rate, weaken contractions, and slow conduction. They are "valium for the heart."

data.fact: A, AA, AAA mnemonic: A = Antianginal (reduces heart workload). AA = Antiarrhythmic (slows SA/AV conduction). AAA = Antihypertensive (vasodilation lowers BP).
data.alert: Common CCBs: Diltiazem (Cardizem), Verapamil (Calan), Amlodipine (Norvasc), Nifedipine (Procardia). If SBP <90, HOLD the CCB. Can be given IV drip.
data.q: The mnemonic "A, AA, AAA" for calcium channel blockers stands for:
data.rationale: CCBs serve three roles: Antianginal (reduce cardiac workload), Antiarrhythmic (control rate), and Antihypertensive (vasodilation to lower BP).

data.fact: H-H side effects: Headache (vasodilation causes migraine-like headaches, common with SATA questions) and Hypotension (vasodilation lowers BP). Monitor BP before and after administration.
data.alert: Hold CCB if SBP <90. Nifedipine (Procardia) is the strongest vasodilator — most likely to cause headache and hypotension. Constipation is also common with verapamil.
data.q: A patient on nifedipine (Procardia) reports a severe headache. The nurse understands this is:
a: An expected side effect from vasodilation
data.rationale: Headache is a common CCB side effect caused by vasodilation (H-H: Headache and Hypotension). It is expected, especially with nifedipine, the strongest vasodilator.

data.fact: Key words for rhythm identification: V-Tach = "bizarre" wide QRS. V-Fib = "chaotic" with NO pattern. Asystole = flat line, no QRS. A-Flutter = "sawtooth" P-waves. A-Fib = chaotic fibrillatory waves. Normal Sinus = normal P, QRS, T equally spaced.
data.alert: Lethal rhythms with NO cardiac output: V-Fib and Asystole — start CPR immediately. V-Tach MAY have a pulse — check first. If no pulse, treat like V-Fib.
data.q: A "chaotic" rhythm with NO identifiable pattern on the monitor indicates:
data.rationale: V-Fib is described as "chaotic" with no identifiable pattern or QRS complexes. It is a lethal rhythm with no cardiac output requiring immediate defibrillation.

data.fact: No cardiac output? No pulse = CPR. V-Fib: no cardiac output, no pulse — DEFIBRILLATE + CPR. Asystole: no cardiac output — CPR + epinephrine (do NOT defibrillate a flat line). V-Tach: check pulse FIRST. Pulseless V-Tach = defibrillate. V-Tach WITH pulse = amiodarone or lidocaine.
data.alert: Without CO there is no pulse. Without a pulse, there is no brain perfusion — confusion/death in 8 minutes. Start CPR within seconds.
data.q: A patient goes into ventricular fibrillation. The FIRST nursing action is:
a: Begin CPR and call for defibrillator
data.rationale: V-Fib is a lethal rhythm with no cardiac output. Immediate CPR and defibrillation are required. Do not delay to call the physician or check BP.

data.fact: Treatment by rhythm: PVCs/V-Tach = Lidocaine or Amiodarone. Atrial rhythms = ABCD (Adenosine, Beta-blockers, CCBs, Digoxin/Lanoxin). V-Fib/Asystole = Defibrillation + CPR + Epinephrine. Bradycardia = Atropine or Pacemaker. SVT = Adenosine (first-line).
data.alert: When dealing with an IV push drug you don't know: go SLOW, except adenosine — adenosine must be pushed FAST (6mg rapid IV push, flush immediately).
data.q: The first-line treatment for supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) is:
data.rationale: Adenosine is the first-line drug for SVT. It is given as a rapid IV push (6mg) followed by an immediate flush because it has an extremely short half-life (6-10 seconds).

data.fact: ABCD for atrial dysrhythmias: A = Adenosine (SVT first-line). B = Beta-blockers (metoprolol, atenolol) — negative chronotropic. C = CCBs (diltiazem, verapamil) — same side effects as CCBs ("H-H"). D = Digoxin/Lanoxin — know all these names.
data.alert: These are like valium: they treat A-Fib/A-Flutter using letter progression. CCB is used for patients with respiratory bronchoconstriction (CCB is used when beta-blockers are contraindicated in asthma/COPD).
data.q: A patient with atrial fibrillation and a history of COPD would MOST appropriately receive:
data.rationale: Beta-blockers can cause bronchoconstriction and are contraindicated in COPD/asthma. CCBs (diltiazem) are the preferred alternative for rate control in atrial fibrillation with COPD.

data.fact: Trough: drawn when drug is at its LOWEST concentration (right BEFORE next dose). Peak: drawn when drug is at its HIGHEST concentration (after administration). "TAP" = Trough, Administer, Peak.
data.alert: Trough and peak timing varies: SQ meds (5-10 min before, 1-2 hr after). IM (30-50 min after). IV (15-30 min after). For NCLEX: if you must choose only one, go with the highest time without going over.
data.q: When should a trough level be drawn?
a: Right before the next scheduled dose
data.rationale: A trough level is drawn when the drug concentration is at its lowest point — right BEFORE the next scheduled dose. This ensures the drug level has not dropped below therapeutic range.

data.alert: Low O2 drive. Max 2L/min.
data.q: What is the maximum O2 flow for a COPD patient?
data.rationale: COPD patients breathe based on hypoxic drive; high O2 levels can knock out their drive to breathe.

data.alert: Encourage fluids to thin secretions.
data.q: What is a priority nursing intervention for Pneumonia?
data.rationale: Hydration thins the mucus, making it easier to expectorate and clear the airway.

data.alert: Negative pressure room. N95 mask.
data.q: Which isolation precaution is used for TB?
data.rationale: TB is transmitted via small airborne particles, requiring a negative pressure room and N95 respirators.

data.alert: Never examine throat (spasm risk).
data.q: What should you NEVER do for a child with Epiglottitis?
a: Examine the throat with a tongue blade
data.rationale: Stimulating the gag reflex can cause complete laryngospasm and airway obstruction.

data.fact: Remove air/fluid. Water seal prevents backflow.
data.alert: Continuous bubbling in water seal = LEAK.
data.q: What does continuous bubbling in the water seal chamber indicate?
data.rationale: The water seal should only bubble intermittently (tidaling); continuous bubbling means air is leaking into the system.

data.alert: ABG: Hypoxemia, Hypercapnia, Resp Acidosis.
data.q: What would the ABG of a client with COPD show?
data.rationale: COPD causes air trapping, leading to CO2 retention (Hypercapnia/Acidosis) and poor oxygenation (Hypoxemia).

data.alert: Fingers: Clubbing.
data.q: What does the chest of a client with COPD look like?
data.rationale: Chronic air trapping expands the chest wall, creating a barrel shape.

data.alert: Result: Air Trapping.
data.q: In emphysema, the alveoli are:
data.rationale: The alveolar walls are destroyed, creating large air sacs that trap air and cannot exchange gas effectively.

data.alert: Type: Pink Puffer/Cyanotic.
data.q: To control SOB, what technique should be taught?
data.rationale: Pursed lip breathing creates back pressure to keep airways open longer during exhalation.

data.alert: Fluids: 3 Liters/day (Force fluids).
data.q: What fluid order should the emphysema client have?
data.rationale: Fluids help liquefy secretions, making them easier to clear.

data.alert: Mechanism: Blow off CO2 > Consolidation traps.
data.q: Which blood gas disorder is most common in pneumonia?
data.rationale: Early pneumonia causes hyperventilation due to hypoxia and pain, blowing off CO2 (Alkalosis).

data.alert: Source: DVT (Legs).
data.q: Where do the emboli that cause pulmonary embolus usually come from?
data.rationale: Deep vein thromboses (DVT) in the legs break off and travel to the lungs.

data.alert: 1st Sign: Dyspnea.
data.q: What is the first sign of pulmonary embolus?
data.rationale: Sudden shortness of breath is the hallmark early sign of PE.

data.fact: Fluid in lungs from Left Ventricular Failure.
data.alert: Sputum: Bloody and Frothy.
data.q: When pulmonary edema is severe what does the sputum look like?
data.rationale: Fluid pushing into alveoli mixes with air to create froth; capillary rupture adds blood (pink).

data.alert: Immediate: Elevate HOB, O2, Call MD.
data.q: What drug is used in pulmonary edema to reduce fluid in the lungs?
data.rationale: Lasix is a potent diuretic that rapidly removes fluid from the lungs.

data.alert: Isolation: Airborne (Negative Pressure).
data.q: The Mantoux test is considered positive if the induration is greater than:
data.rationale: For general population, >10mm is positive. (>5mm for HIV/Immunocompromised).

data.alert: Side FX: Peripheral Neuritis (B6), Red Urine (Rifampin).
data.q: What colors will Rifampin turn urine, sweat, and tears?
data.rationale: Rifampin causes harmless red-orange discoloration of body fluids.

data.alert: Non-contagious: After 3 negative sputum cultures.
data.q: How many consecutive sputum cultures need to be negative for the client to be non-contagious?
data.rationale: Three consecutive negative smears are the gold standard for clearance.

data.alert: Signs: Retractions, Flaring, Grunting.
data.q: The cause of RDS is a lack of:
data.rationale: Surfactant keeps alveoli open; without it, they collapse (atelectasis).

data.alert: O2 Toxicity: Retrolental Fibroplasia (Blindness).
data.q: High flow rates of O2 delivered in RDS can cause:
data.rationale: Excess oxygen causes abnormal blood vessel growth in the retina, leading to blindness.

data.fact: Muffled voice, Drooling, Stridor. Tripod position.
data.alert: NEVER: Put tongue blade in mouth.
data.q: If a child is suspected of having epiglottitis, should you put a tongue depressor in their mouth?
data.rationale: It triggers laryngospasm.

data.alert: Systems: Lungs & Pancreas.
data.q: In which two systems/organs are the most problems in CF?
data.rationale: Thick mucus clogs the airways (Lungs) and digestive ducts (Pancreas).

data.alert: Diet: High Calorie, High Protein.
data.q: What is the classic test for CF?
data.rationale: CF patients excrete excessive salt in their sweat.

data.alert: Admin: With meals.
data.q: When should the child with CF take his pancreatic enzymes?
data.rationale: Enzymes must be present when food enters the GI tract to aid digestion.

data.alert: Signs: Wheezing, SOB, Cough (at night).
data.q: When will the client with asthma experience the cough?
data.rationale: Nocturnal coughing is a common asthma symptom due to circadian drops in cortisol/epinephrine.

data.alert: Order: Give Bronchodilator FIRST.
data.q: Which should you give first-the steroid or bronchodilator?
data.rationale: Bronchodilators open the airway so the steroid can reach the lungs.

data.alert: Time: Max 10 sec.
data.q: For how long should suction be applied during any one entry?
data.rationale: Prolonged suctioning causes hypoxia and vagal stimulation (bradycardia).

data.alert: Safety: Obturator at bedside.
data.q: What must the nurse always have at the bedside of a trach patient?
data.rationale: The obturator is needed to re-insert the tube if it accidentally falls out.

data.alert: Stridor Cause: Laryngeal spasm/swelling.
data.q: What is the cause of stridor?
data.rationale: Stridor is a high-pitched upper airway sound indicating obstruction/swelling.

data.fact: Ascending potency: Nasal Cannula → Simple Face Mask → Partial Rebreather → Nonrebreather → Venturi (most precise).
data.alert: Venturi mask delivers most precise FiO2 concentration.
data.q: Which O2 delivery device delivers the most precise oxygen concentration?
data.rationale: The Venturi mask uses a mixing device to deliver a precise FiO2, making it ideal for COPD patients.

data.fact: Max 6L/min by nasal cannula. Humidify if >4L/hr. COPD: max 2L/min.
data.alert: COPD >2L = CO2 Narcosis (knocks out hypoxic drive).
data.q: What is the maximum O2 flow rate by nasal cannula?
data.rationale: Nasal cannula can deliver up to 6L/min; higher flows require a mask. COPD patients are limited to 2L/min.

data.fact: Blue Bloater. Cyanosis, right-sided heart failure (cor pulmonale), bloating/edema, productive cough.
data.alert: vs Emphysema = Pink Puffer (pursed lip breathing, barrel chest).
data.q: A "Blue Bloater" describes which condition?
data.rationale: Chronic Bronchitis causes chronic hypoxemia (blue) and right-sided heart failure with edema (bloater).

data.fact: Inhale slowly and completely. Target flow 600-900. Hold breath 5 seconds.
data.alert: Frequency: 10 times per hour. Sit upright for best results.
data.q: How often should a post-op patient use the incentive spirometer?
data.rationale: Frequent use (10x/hr) prevents atelectasis by expanding alveoli and keeping them open.

data.fact: Every 2 hours. Sit up straight. Deep breath through nose, slowly out through pursed lips.
data.alert: Hold last breath 3 seconds. Cough 3 times. Splint abd wound if applicable.
data.q: How often should post-op breathing exercises be performed?
data.rationale: Every 2 hours prevents atelectasis and pneumonia, the most common post-op pulmonary complications.

data.fact: Alarms must always be ON. Check patient every 4 hours minimum.
data.alert: High pressure alarm = obstruction/secretions. Low pressure alarm = disconnection/leak.
data.q: A high pressure alarm on a ventilator most likely indicates:
data.rationale: High pressure means resistance is increased - from mucus plugs, kinking, biting the tube, or bronchospasm.

data.fact: Restlessness and Irritability = Early signs of cerebral hypoxia.
data.alert: Priority: Check O2 saturation and airway FIRST. Do not sedate!
data.q: A post-op patient becomes restless and irritable. The nurse should first:
data.rationale: Restlessness is an early sign of hypoxia; checking O2 status is the priority before assuming anxiety.

data.fact: If disconnected: place end in sterile water. Removal: Valsalva or deep breath and hold.
data.alert: Water seal shows tidaling (fluctuation with breathing) = normal. Keep scissors at bedside for S. Blakemore tube.
data.q: If a chest tube becomes disconnected, the nurse should:
a: Place the end in sterile water
data.rationale: Placing the end in sterile water creates a temporary water seal to prevent air from entering the pleural space.

data.fact: Weaning parameters — patient must meet ALL criteria before extubation: PaO2 ≥60 mmHg on FiO2 ≤40%. PaCO2 within normal limits (35-45 mmHg). Tidal volume ≥5 mL/kg. Vital capacity ≥10-15 mL/kg. Respiratory rate <25 breaths/min. Negative inspiratory force (NIF) stronger than -20 cmH2O (e.g., -25 is adequate). Patient is alert, follows commands, and has a gag/cough reflex.
data.alert: Key point: if ANY parameter is not met, the patient is NOT ready to wean. Schedule weaning trials during the DAY when the patient is rested — never start at night. Elevate HOB 30-45 degrees. Keep intubation equipment at bedside during and after extubation. Monitor closely for 24-48 hours post-extubation.
data.q: Which finding indicates a patient is NOT ready for ventilator weaning?
data.rationale: A respiratory rate of 30 exceeds the weaning threshold of <25 breaths/min. All other values are within acceptable ranges. ALL criteria must be met simultaneously before weaning can begin.

data.fact: Simple pneumothorax: Air in pleural space → partial lung collapse. Causes: trauma, rib fracture, ruptured bleb. Signs: dyspnea, decreased breath sounds on affected side, chest pain. Treatment: small = observation + O2; large = chest tube. Tension pneumothorax: LIFE-THREATENING. Air enters but cannot escape (one-way valve). Signs: severe dyspnea, tracheal deviation AWAY from affected side, distended neck veins (JVD), hypotension. Emergency treatment: large-bore needle decompression at 2nd intercostal space midclavicular line, then chest tube.
data.alert: Tracheal deviation = TENSION pneumothorax = EMERGENCY. Do NOT wait for chest X-ray if patient is deteriorating — needle decompression is performed immediately. After chest tube placement, assess for air leak (continuous bubbling in water seal) and lung re-expansion.
data.q: A trauma patient has absent breath sounds on the left, tracheal deviation to the right, and JVD. The PRIORITY intervention is:
data.rationale: Tracheal deviation away from the affected side + JVD + absent breath sounds = tension pneumothorax. This is a medical emergency requiring immediate needle decompression at the 2nd intercostal space, midclavicular line, followed by chest tube insertion.

data.fact: Total laryngectomy: After total laryngectomy, the patient breathes through a permanent tracheostomy (stoma in the neck). There is NO connection between the nose/mouth and the lungs. Key care: humidify inspired air (no natural humidification from nose). Suction via stoma, NOT nose/mouth. Cover stoma loosely with damp gauze (prevents foreign bodies). No swimming EVER. Wear MedicAlert identification.
data.alert: CRITICAL: In a respiratory emergency with a neck breather, do CPR via the STOMA — not mouth-to-mouth. If suctioning is needed, go through the stoma. The patient CANNOT speak normally — provide communication methods (writing board, electrolarynx). Assess for signs of stomal stenosis.
data.q: A patient with a total laryngectomy is found unresponsive and not breathing. The nurse should initiate rescue breaths via the:
data.rationale: After total laryngectomy, there is NO connection between the upper airway and the lungs. All ventilation must be delivered through the stoma. Cover the mouth and nose to prevent air escape during stoma ventilation.

data.fact: ROME for remembering compensation direction: RO = Respiratory Opposite: pH and CO2 move in OPPOSITE directions (pH down + CO2 up = respiratory acidosis). ME = Metabolic Equal: pH and HCO3 move in the SAME direction (pH down + HCO3 down = metabolic acidosis). Normal values: pH 7.35-7.45, CO2 35-45, HCO3 22-26.
data.alert: Step-by-step: 1) Look at pH — acidosis (<7.35) or alkalosis (>7.45)? 2) Check CO2 — if it explains the pH (opposite direction) = respiratory. 3) Check HCO3 — if it explains the pH (same direction) = metabolic. 4) If BOTH are abnormal, the one matching the pH direction is primary. Compensation: if the other value is also abnormal, the body is trying to compensate.
data.q: A patient has pH 7.30, PaCO2 55, HCO3 24. This ABG indicates:
data.rationale: pH 7.30 = acidosis. CO2 55 = elevated (moves opposite to pH → respiratory cause). HCO3 24 = normal (no metabolic compensation yet). Diagnosis: uncompensated respiratory acidosis. Using ROME: RO = Respiratory Opposite (pH down, CO2 up).

data.fact: O2 toxicity: Prolonged exposure to high FiO2 (>50% for >24-48 hours) damages alveolar membranes. Early signs: substernal chest pain, dry cough, dyspnea, fatigue, nausea. Late signs: ARDS-like picture with crackles, progressive respiratory failure. At-risk populations: patients on mechanical ventilation with high FiO2 settings.
data.alert: Prevention: use the LOWEST FiO2 that maintains PaO2 ≥60 mmHg or SpO2 ≥90%%. For COPD patients, keep O2 at 1-2 L/min via nasal cannula (their respiratory drive depends on low O2 levels — high O2 removes the hypoxic drive). Positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) allows lower FiO2 while maintaining oxygenation.
data.q: To prevent oxygen toxicity in a ventilated patient, the nurse should advocate for:
a: Maintaining FiO2 at 100% to ensure maximum oxygenation
Using the lowest FiO2 that keeps PaO2 at or above 60 mmHg
data.rationale: The goal is the LOWEST FiO2 that maintains adequate oxygenation (PaO2 ≥60 or SpO2 ≥90%). FiO2 >50% for >24-48 hours damages alveoli. PEEP can be added to achieve adequate oxygenation at lower FiO2 levels.

data.fact: Peak expiratory flow (PEF) uses a traffic-light system: Green zone (80-100% of personal best) = good control, continue maintenance meds. Yellow zone (50-79% of personal best) = caution, airways narrowing — use rescue inhaler, may need medication adjustment. Red zone (<50% of personal best) = medical EMERGENCY — use rescue inhaler immediately and seek emergency care. Personal best is determined during a 2-3 week period of good control.
data.alert: Always use rescue inhaler (albuterol/SABA) BEFORE using maintenance inhaler (corticosteroid). Wait 1-5 minutes between puffs. Use a spacer to improve medication delivery. Rinse mouth after inhaled corticosteroids to prevent oral thrush (candidiasis).
data.q: A patient with asthma has a peak flow reading that is 45% of their personal best. This falls in the:
data.rationale: Peak flow <50% of personal best = Red zone = medical emergency. The patient should take the rescue inhaler (albuterol) immediately and seek emergency medical care. This indicates severe airway narrowing requiring urgent intervention.
