data.q: The primary stage of syphilis is characterized by:
data.rationale: The primary stage presents with a painless chancre (red lesion) at the site of infection, lasting about 90 days.

data.fact: Neisseria Gonorrhoeae. Yellow-green urethral discharge ("The Clap").
data.alert: Can be asymptomatic in females. Complications: PID, infertility, ophthalmia neonatorum.
data.q: The classic symptom of gonorrhea in males is:
data.rationale: Gonorrhea causes a purulent yellow-green urethral discharge in males, often called "The Clap."

data.fact: Most common STD. Often asymptomatic. Mild vaginal discharge or urethritis.
data.alert: Tx: Doxycycline or Azithromycin. Screen all sexually active women <25 annually.
data.q: Which STD is the most commonly reported in the United States?
data.rationale: Chlamydia is the most common STD; many cases are asymptomatic, making routine screening essential.

data.fact:
Trichomoniasis = frothy, foul-smelling discharge. Tx: Flagyl (avoid alcohol).
Candidiasis = yellow cheesy discharge with itching. Tx: Miconazole, Nystatin.
data.alert: Flagyl + alcohol = severe nausea/vomiting (disulfiram-like reaction).
data.q: Frothy, foul-smelling vaginal discharge is characteristic of:
data.rationale: Trichomoniasis produces a distinctive frothy, greenish-yellow, malodorous discharge.

data.fact: Herpes Simplex 2 = painful genital vesicles. Tx: Acyclovir (manages, no cure). Avoid contact during outbreaks.
data.alert: HPV = genital warts. Tx: Acid, Laser, Cryotherapy. Can lead to cervical cancer. Vaccine available.
data.q: Which STD has NO cure but can be managed with Acyclovir?
data.rationale: Herpes has no cure; Acyclovir reduces outbreak frequency and severity but does not eliminate the virus.

data.fact: Diagnosed with ELISA, confirmed with Western Blot. Tx: Antiretroviral cocktails (HAART).
data.alert: Monitor CD4 count and viral load. Opportunistic infections when CD4 < 200. Standard + body fluid precautions.
data.q: Which lab value indicates a patient with HIV is at high risk for opportunistic infections?
data.rationale: A CD4 count below 200 defines AIDS and indicates severe immunosuppression with high risk for opportunistic infections.

pharm.title: Pharmacology
pharm.description: Drug safety, dosing, interactions, acid-base balance

data.alert: As the pH goes, so goes the patient.
data.q: What happens when pH goes UP (Alkalosis)?
data.rationale: Alkalosis makes the body irritable: high HR, high reflexes, seizures. (Except Potassium goes DOWN).

data.alert: Bradycardia, Lethargy, Coma, Respiratory Arrest.
data.q: What are the signs of Acidosis?
data.rationale: Acidosis depresses the CNS: lethargy, low HR, respiratory arrest. (Potassium goes UP).

data.alert: Occurs in MAC (Metabolic Acidosis).
data.q: Which acid-base imbalance causes Kussmaul respirations?
data.rationale: Remember MAC Kussmaul (Metabolic Acidosis causes Kussmaul to blow off CO2).

data.alert: Low Press = Disconnection.
data.q: What causes a High Pressure ventilator alarm?
data.rationale: High pressure means the machine has to push harder against resistance (kinked tube, secretions).

data.alert: Ototoxicity (Ears) & Nephrotoxicity (Kidneys).
data.q: What are the toxic effects of Aminoglycosides (Gentamicin)?
data.rationale: Think mice (mycin) have big ears (Oto) and kidneys are shaped like ears (Nephro).

data.alert: Trough: 30 min before dose. Peak: Depends on route.
data.q: When is a trough level drawn?
data.rationale: Trough is the lowest concentration, always drawn immediately before the next dose is given.

data.fact: Uppers: Caffeine, Cocaine, PCP/LSD, Meth, Adderall.
data.alert: S/S: High HR, BP, Seizures.
data.q: What are the symptoms of an "Upper" overdose?
data.rationale: Uppers stimulate the CNS; everything goes UP.

data.alert: Overdose = Resp Arrest.
data.q: What is the priority for a "Downer" overdose?
data.rationale: Downers depress the CNS; too much can stop breathing.

data.alert: Upper Withdrawal = Down. Downer Withdrawal = Up.
data.q: What happens during withdrawal from a Downer?
data.rationale: The body was suppressed; remove the suppressant and the body rebounds upward (seizures, tachycardia).

data.alert: Max 40 mEq/L. High K+ stops heart.
data.q: How should Potassium never be administered?
data.rationale: IV Push potassium causes instant cardiac arrest. Always dilute in a bag.

data.alert: Calms heart. Lowers BP.
data.q: What is the effect of Calcium Channel Blockers?
data.rationale: They are negative inotropes, chronotropes, and dromotropes (weaken, slow, and block conduction).

data.alert: Lower HR/BP. Do not give to Asthmatics.
data.q: Why are Beta Blockers contraindicated in Asthma?
data.rationale: Non-selective beta blockers block beta-2 receptors in the lungs, causing constriction.

data.alert: Bleeding precautions.
data.q: Which lab monitors Coumadin (Warfarin)?
data.rationale: PT/INR is for Coumadin. PTT is for Heparin.

data.alert: S/E: Fatigue, Muscle weakness. Don't drink alcohol.
data.q: What patient teaching is needed for Baclofen (Lioresal)?
data.rationale: It relaxes muscles and sedates the CNS; combining with alcohol enhances sedation.

data.alert: For Malignant Hyperthermia.
data.q: What drug treats Malignant Hyperthermia?
data.rationale: Dantrolene acts directly on skeletal muscle to stop the rigidity and heat production.

data.alert: "K-Exits-Late". Gives Na, kicks out K.
data.q: How does Kayexalate work?
a: Exchanges Sodium for Potassium in the gut
data.rationale: It acts as a resin in the bowel, trading sodium ions for potassium ions, which are pooped out.

data.alert: Clear solution.
data.q: Which insulin can be given IV drip?
data.rationale: Regular insulin is the only one safe for IV administration.

data.alert: IM: 30-60 min.
data.q: When do you draw a peak level for an IV drug?
data.rationale: This captures the highest concentration in the blood.

data.alert: For everyone.
data.q: When are Standard Precautions used?
data.rationale: Standard precautions apply to contact with blood, body fluids, non-intact skin, and mucous membranes for all patients.

data.alert: Gown + Gloves.
data.q: Which diseases require Contact Precautions?
a: MRSA, RSV, Staph, Wound infections, Enteric (C-diff)
data.rationale: Contact is for anything transmitted by touching skin or surfaces (MRS. WEE mnemonic).

data.alert: Mask + Goggles.
data.q: Which diseases require Droplet Precautions?
a: Sepsis, Scarlet Fever, Strep, Pertussis, Pneumonia, Flu, Meningitis
data.rationale: Droplets travel 3 feet; a mask is required. (SPIDERMAN mnemonic).

data.alert: N95 Mask + Neg Pressure Room.
data.q: Which diseases require Airborne Precautions?
data.rationale: Tiny particles float in the air. MTV mnemonic: Measles, TB, Varicella.

data.alert: Up the body, then hands.
data.q: What is the correct order for putting on PPE?
data.rationale: Start big (Gown), move up to face (Mask/Goggles), end with hands (Gloves).

data.alert: Gloves, Goggles, Gown, Mask.
data.q: What is the correct order for removing PPE?
data.rationale: Remove dirtiest first (Gloves), protect face/airway last (Mask).

data.alert: New order q24h. MD check within 1h.
data.q: How often must a restraint order be renewed for an adult?
data.rationale: Restraints are highly regulated; orders expire daily.

data.alert: Cane goes with bad leg.
data.q: What is the COAL mnemonic for canes?
data.rationale: You hold the cane on the strong side to support the weak side.

data.fact: Even for Even, Odd for Odd.
data.alert: 2-point/4-point = Even weakness. 3-point = Odd (1 leg).
data.q: Use an even-numbered gait (2 or 4) when weakness is...?
data.rationale: If both legs are weak (bilateral), use 2-point or 4-point. If one leg is broken (unilateral/odd), use 3-point.

data.alert: Unstable > Stable.
data.q: Who is the priority patient?
data.rationale: The patient with a new, changing, or unstable condition always comes first.

data.alert: Brain > Lungs > Heart > Liver > Kidney > Pancreas.
data.q: In a tie for priority, use the modifying phrase to find the...?
data.rationale: If two patients are unstable, prioritize the one with the more vital organ failure (Brain/Lung vs Kidney).

data.alert: No IVs, No Teaching, No Assessment (Admission).
data.q: Can an LPN perform an admission assessment?
data.rationale: Admission/Discharge assessments require advanced judgment and planning; RN only.

data.alert: Vitals, ADLs, Hygiene.
data.q: Can a UAP take vitals on a stable patient?
data.rationale: Routine vitals on stable patients are within the UAP scope.

data.alert: Relieves nerve compression.
data.q: What is the difference between Laminectomy and Laminotomy?
data.rationale: Ectomy removes the whole lamina; Otomy removes a small part to make space.

data.fact:
Hgb: M 14-18, F 12-16.
Hct: M 42-52, F 37-47.
WBCs: 4.5-11k.
Platelets: 150-400k.
data.alert: PT (Coumadin): 11-12.5 sec, INR 1.5-2x normal. APTT (Heparin): 60-70 sec, 1.5-2.5x normal.
data.q: The normal platelet count range is:
data.rationale: Normal platelet count is 150,000-400,000; below 150k is thrombocytopenia with bleeding risk.

data.alert: Albumin: 3.5-5. Bilirubin newborn: 1-12. HgbA1c: 4-6% ideal, <7.5% OK.
data.q: Which lab value best reflects long-term glucose control?
data.rationale: HgbA1c reflects average blood glucose over the past 2-3 months (120 days = RBC lifespan).

data.alert: Cl- 96-106. Phos 3-4.5. Spec Gravity 1.005-1.030. Dilantin TR: 10-20. Lithium TR: 0.5-1.5.
data.q: The normal potassium range is:
data.rationale: Normal K+ is 3.5-5.0 mEq/L; values outside this range can cause life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias.

data.fact:
Digoxin → Digiband.
Coumadin → Vitamin K.
Heparin → Protamine Sulfate.
Benzos → Flumazenil.
MgSO4 → Calcium Gluconate.
Tylenol → Mucomist.
Opiates → Narcan.
Methotrexate → Leucovorin.
data.alert: Know these cold for NCLEX! Each antidote reverses a specific toxicity.
data.q: The antidote for Heparin overdose is:
data.rationale: Protamine Sulfate binds to heparin molecules, neutralizing their anticoagulant effect.

data.fact: Bottom to top: 1. Physiologic (ABCs, food, water). 2. Safety. 3. Love/Belonging. 4. Esteem. 5. Self-actualization.
data.alert: On NCLEX: Always address lower levels FIRST. Physiologic needs before psychosocial.
data.q: According to Maslow, which need takes priority?
data.rationale: Physiologic needs (airway, breathing, circulation) are the foundation; they must be met before higher-level needs.

data.alert: Assessment is ALWAYS first unless patient is in danger. NCLEX: "assess" before "implement."
data.q: A nurse enters a room and finds a new problem. The FIRST step is:
data.rationale: Assessment is always the first step in the nursing process before any intervention can be planned or implemented.

data.fact: Airway → Breathing → Circulation. Airway is ALWAYS first priority.
data.alert: Exception: uncontrolled hemorrhage (stop bleeding first). On NCLEX: airway answer is usually correct.
data.q: When prioritizing patient care, the nurse addresses which need FIRST?
data.rationale: Airway always comes first in ABC prioritization — without a patent airway, breathing and circulation are impossible.

data.fact: End in "-pril": Captopril, Enalapril, Lisinopril. First-dose hypotension risk.
data.alert: Stay in bed 3 hours after first dose. SE: dry cough, hyperK+, angioedema. Contraindicated in pregnancy.
data.q: A common side effect of ACE inhibitors is:
data.rationale: ACE inhibitors cause a characteristic dry, hacking cough due to bradykinin accumulation in the lungs.

data.fact: End in "-statin": Atorvastatin (Lipitor), Simvastatin (Zocor). Take in PM only.
data.alert: No grapefruit juice (inhibits metabolism → toxicity). Monitor liver function (hepatotoxicity risk).
data.q: Why should statins be taken in the evening?
data.rationale: Cholesterol synthesis in the liver peaks at night; evening dosing maximizes the drug's effectiveness.

data.fact:
Isotonic: D5W, NS (0.9% NaCl), Ringer's Lactate.
NS only with blood products and Dilantin.
data.alert: Hypertonic (D10W, 3% NaCl): pulls fluid IN. Hypotonic (0.45% NaCl): fluid shifts OUT.
data.q: Which IV solution is used with blood product administration?
data.rationale: Normal Saline is the only solution compatible with blood products; others cause hemolysis or clotting.

data.fact: Flow Rate (gtts/min) = Total mL × Drop Factor / 60 × Hours.
data.alert: Round drops to nearest whole drop. Round mL/hr to nearest full mL. Include leading zero for values <1.
data.q: To calculate IV flow rate in gtts/min, you need to know:
data.rationale: The IV flow rate formula requires total volume, drop factor (from tubing package), and infusion time.

data.fact: 1 tsp = 5 mL. 1 Tbsp = 15 mL. 1 oz = 30 mL. 1 cup = 240 mL. 1 kg = 2.2 lbs. 1 grain = 60 mg.
data.alert: Pediatric doses rounded to nearest 100th and rounded DOWN. Must include leading zero (0.5, not .5).
data.q: How many mL are in 1 ounce?
data.rationale: One ounce equals 30 mL (or 30 cc). This is a critical conversion for medication calculations.

data.q: A temperature of 38°C equals:
data.rationale: 38°C = 100.4°F, which is the threshold for fever in most clinical settings.

data.fact: Room close to nurses station. Bed low with side rails up. Good lighting. Non-slip footwear.
data.alert: Help to stand (dangle feet first). Consistent toileting schedule. At home: bright stairs, bells on pets.
data.q: Which intervention is the priority for fall prevention?
data.rationale: Non-restrictive measures like bed alarms, non-slip footwear, and environmental modifications are first-line fall prevention.

data.fact: Teach breathing exercises in advance. NPO for 8 hours. Remove nail polish. Void before surgery.
data.alert: No NSAIDs for 48 hrs. Increased corticosteroids for surgery stress may increase insulin needs.
data.q: A patient scheduled for surgery tomorrow should be NPO for:
data.rationale: NPO for 8 hours before surgery prevents aspiration of stomach contents during anesthesia.

data.fact: Restlessness may indicate hemorrhage or hypoxia. VS: q15min x1hr, q30min x2hr, q1hr x4hr, then q4hr.
data.alert: Call MD if: UO <30 mL/hr, SBP <90, T >100 or <96. Stages: Immediate (1-4h), Intermediate (2-24h), Extended (1-4d).
data.q: A post-op patient becomes restless. The nurse should FIRST:
data.rationale: Post-op restlessness is a red flag for hemorrhage or hypoxia and must be assessed before attributing it to anxiety.

data.fact:
THR: no adduction/midline, no hip flexion >90°.
Supratentorial Sx: HOB 30-45° (Semi-Fowler).
Infratentorial Sx: Flat.
data.alert: Liver Biopsy: Right side against puncture. Amputation: Supine, elevate stump 48 hrs.
data.q: After supratentorial surgery, the patient should be positioned:
data.rationale: Semi-Fowler's promotes venous drainage from the brain, reducing intracranial pressure after supratentorial surgery.

data.fact:
Enema: Left Sims (sigmoid).
Liver Biopsy: Right side post-procedure.
Thoracocentesis: Sit up, lean forward.
data.alert: Cardiac Cath: Flat, HOB ≤30°, leg straight. Cataract Sx: Opposite side, Semi-Fowler.
data.q: The correct position for a patient receiving an enema is:
data.rationale: Left Sims position allows the enema solution to flow with gravity into the sigmoid colon for optimal effectiveness.

data.fact:
Rifampin (TB) = rust/orange/red urine and body fluids.
Pyridium (bladder) = orange/red/pink urine.
data.alert: Iron supplements = black/tarry stools. These color changes are expected — teach patients!
data.q: A patient on Rifampin should be told that their urine may turn:
data.rationale: Rifampin causes harmless red-orange discoloration of urine, sweat, tears, and other body fluids.

data.alert: Often combined with Lasix (loop diuretic) to balance K+. Also combined with ACE inhibitors.
data.q: The primary risk of potassium-sparing diuretics is:
data.rationale: Potassium-sparing diuretics retain K+, risking dangerous hyperkalemia, especially when combined with ACE inhibitors.

data.fact:
Trousseau's (carpal spasm w/ BP cuff) = Hypocalcemia.
Chvostek's (facial twitch) = Hypocalcemia.
Cullen's (periumbilical bruising) = Pancreatitis.
Turner's (flank bruising) = Pancreatitis.
data.alert: Murphy's Sign (RUQ pain on inspiration) = Cholecystitis. Gower's Sign = Muscular Dystrophy.
data.q: Trousseau's sign is associated with:
data.rationale: Trousseau's sign (carpal spasm induced by inflating a BP cuff) indicates hypocalcemia/hypoparathyroidism.

data.fact:
Tensilon Test = Myasthenia Gravis.
ELISA + Western Blot = HIV.
Sweat Test = CF (>60 mEq/L Cl-).
data.alert: Mantoux/PPD = TB (>10mm at 48 hrs). Guthrie Test = PKU. Ballard Scale = Gestational Age.
data.q: A positive Tensilon test confirms the diagnosis of:
data.rationale: The Tensilon (Edrophonium) test temporarily improves muscle weakness in Myasthenia Gravis, confirming the diagnosis.

data.fact: Know the class by the suffix: -olol = beta-blocker (propranolol, atenolol, metoprolol). -pril = ACE inhibitor (lisinopril, enalapril, captopril). -sartan = ARB (losartan, valsartan, irbesartan). -statin = statin (atorvastatin, simvastatin). -prazole = proton pump inhibitor (omeprazole, pantoprazole). -pam / -lam = benzodiazepine (lorazepam, diazepam, midazolam). -sone / -solone = glucocorticoid (prednisone, dexamethasone).
data.alert: NCLEX loves testing: "Which medication should the nurse question?" If you know the suffix → you know the class → you know the side effects and contraindications. Example: -olol = beta-blocker = bradycardia risk = hold if HR <60.
data.q: A patient is prescribed a new medication ending in "-sartan." The nurse recognizes this drug belongs to which class?
data.rationale: The suffix -sartan identifies ARBs (losartan, valsartan). ARBs block angiotensin II receptors to lower BP. Unlike ACE inhibitors (-pril), ARBs do NOT cause a dry cough because they do not affect bradykinin levels.

data.fact: Must-know levels: Digoxin = 0.5-2.0 ng/mL (toxicity: N/V, yellow-green halos, bradycardia). Lithium = 0.6-1.2 mEq/L (toxicity: tremors, confusion, seizures; hold if >1.5). Phenytoin (Dilantin) = 10-20 mcg/mL (toxicity: nystagmus, ataxia, gingival hyperplasia). Theophylline = 10-20 mcg/mL (toxicity: tachycardia, restlessness, seizures). Salicylate (aspirin) = 15-40 mcg/mL (toxicity: tinnitus, GI bleeding).
data.alert: Before giving digoxin: check apical pulse × 1 full minute. Hold if <60 BPM in adults, <100 in children. Lithium: must have adequate sodium and fluid intake — dehydration and low sodium INCREASE lithium levels → toxicity. Draw lithium level 12 hours after last dose.
data.q: A patient on digoxin reports seeing yellow-green halos around lights. The digoxin level is 2.8 ng/mL. The nurse should FIRST:
a: Hold the medication and notify the provider
Give an additional dose to reach therapeutic level
data.rationale: Digoxin therapeutic range is 0.5-2.0 ng/mL. A level of 2.8 is toxic. Yellow-green halos are a classic sign of digoxin toxicity along with N/V and bradycardia. Hold the dose and notify the provider immediately.

data.fact: Safe dose calculation: Step 1 — Get the child's weight in kg (lbs ÷ 2.2). Step 2 — Multiply weight by the LOW end of the mg/kg range = minimum safe dose. Step 3 — Multiply weight by the HIGH end = maximum safe dose. Step 4 — Compare the ordered dose. If ordered dose falls WITHIN the range = safe to give. If ABOVE the max = hold and notify provider.
data.alert: Key rule: if the question asks you to calculate a safe dose and the ordered dose is ABOVE the recommended range, the answer is ALWAYS "hold and notify the provider" — never give it and never adjust it yourself. Nurses do NOT change medication doses independently.
data.q: A child weighs 44 lbs. The safe dose range is 10-15 mg/kg/day. The ordered dose is 350 mg/day. The nurse should:
a: Hold the dose and notify the provider
data.rationale: 44 lbs ÷ 2.2 = 20 kg. Low: 20 × 10 = 200 mg. High: 20 × 15 = 300 mg. Safe range: 200-300 mg/day. Ordered dose (350 mg) exceeds the maximum — hold and notify the provider.

data.fact: Mixing rule: When mixing Regular (clear) and NPH (cloudy) insulin in one syringe: draw up clear (Regular) FIRST, then cloudy (NPH). Memory aid: "RN" = Regular before NPH, or "Clear before Cloudy." Rationale: if cloudy NPH contaminates the Regular vial, it would alter the Regular insulin's rapid onset for ALL future doses from that vial.
data.alert: Never mix Lantus (glargine) or Levemir (detemir) with any other insulin — they are given ALONE. Regular is the ONLY insulin given IV. NPH is the ONLY insulin that is cloudy. Roll NPH gently to mix — never shake (causes air bubbles and protein breakdown).
data.q: When preparing to mix Regular and NPH insulin, the nurse should draw up which insulin FIRST?
a: Either one — order does not matter
data.rationale: "Clear before Cloudy" — draw Regular (clear, fast-acting) first, then NPH (cloudy, intermediate). This prevents NPH from contaminating the Regular insulin vial. Memory aid: "RN" = Regular before NPH.

data.fact: MAOIs (phenelzine, tranylcypromine, isocarboxazid): Used for treatment-resistant depression. Inhibit MAO enzyme that normally breaks down tyramine. Eating tyramine-rich foods causes tyramine crisis: sudden, severe hypertension (BP can exceed 200 systolic), throbbing headache, stiff neck, sweating, palpitations. Can lead to stroke.
data.alert: AVOID foods high in tyramine: aged cheese (cheddar, Swiss, Parmesan), red wine, beer, smoked/cured meats (salami, pepperoni), soy sauce, sauerkraut, pickled foods, overripe bananas/avocados. Also avoid: pseudoephedrine, other antidepressants (serotonin syndrome risk). Dietary restrictions continue 2-4 WEEKS after stopping MAOI.
data.q: A patient taking an MAOI reports eating aged cheddar cheese and now has a severe headache with BP 210/120. This reaction is caused by:
data.rationale: MAOIs block tyramine breakdown. Aged cheese is high in tyramine, causing massive norepinephrine release → hypertensive crisis. Symptoms: severe headache, stiff neck, BP >200. This is a medical emergency requiring immediate treatment.

data.fact: Six Rights: 1) Right PATIENT (two identifiers — name and DOB, never room number). 2) Right MEDICATION (compare MAR to label three times). 3) Right DOSE (calculate and verify, especially pediatric). 4) Right ROUTE (PO, IV, IM, SQ, etc.). 5) Right TIME (within 30 min of scheduled time). 6) Right DOCUMENTATION (chart immediately after giving).
data.alert: Additional rights recognized: Right REASON (does this drug make sense for this patient?), Right RESPONSE (did the medication achieve its intended effect?), Right to REFUSE (patient can decline — document and notify provider). NEVER leave medications at the bedside unless specifically ordered (e.g., nitroglycerin).
data.q: A nurse is preparing to administer medication. Which patient identifier is UNACCEPTABLE?
data.rationale: Room number is NEVER an acceptable patient identifier because patients move rooms. Use at least TWO identifiers: name and DOB, name and medical record number, or name and barcode scan. This is a Joint Commission National Patient Safety Goal.

data.fact: Key interactions: Warfarin + Vitamin K foods (leafy greens) = decreased anticoagulant effect — maintain CONSISTENT intake, do not eliminate. Tetracycline/Fluoroquinolones + dairy/calcium/antacids = reduced absorption — take on empty stomach. Many drugs + grapefruit juice = increased drug levels (inhibits CYP3A4 enzyme) — affects statins, CCBs, cyclosporine. ACE inhibitors/K+ sparing diuretics + potassium-rich foods = hyperkalemia risk (bananas, oranges, potatoes).
data.alert: Key tip: Warfarin question + food = vitamin K is the answer. The key is CONSISTENCY, not avoidance. Grapefruit makes drug levels go UP. Dairy/calcium makes antibiotic levels go DOWN. When in doubt about a food-drug interaction, answer "notify the provider."
data.q: A patient on warfarin asks about dietary changes. The BEST nursing instruction is:
a: Maintain a consistent intake of vitamin K-rich foods
Increase vitamin K intake to enhance the drug effect
Eat grapefruit daily to boost absorption
data.rationale: Patients on warfarin should maintain CONSISTENT vitamin K intake — not eliminate it. Sudden increases or decreases in vitamin K foods (leafy greens, broccoli) alter the INR unpredictably. The goal is stability, not restriction.

data.fact: RN ONLY: Assessment, Teaching, Evaluation, Care Plans, IV meds, Blood products, Triage.
data.alert: If it requires nursing JUDGMENT, it cannot be delegated.
data.q: Which task can ONLY be performed by the RN?
a: Patient teaching about a new medication
data.rationale: Teaching requires nursing judgment and assessment of understanding — it cannot be delegated to UAPs or LPNs.

data.fact: LPN/LVN can: Give PO/IM/SQ meds, dressing changes, suctioning, catheter care, stable patient monitoring.
data.alert: LPNs CANNOT: assess, teach, give IV push meds, or make care plans. Can reinforce teaching.
data.q: An LPN can perform which task?
data.rationale: LPNs can administer PO, IM, and SQ medications; they cannot do initial assessments, teaching, or IV push meds.

data.fact: UAP/CNA can: Vital signs, I&O, bathing, feeding, ambulation, daily weights, specimen collection.
data.alert: UAPs perform tasks that are routine, non-sterile, and do NOT require judgment.
data.q: Which task is appropriate for a UAP?
data.rationale: I&O measurement is a routine task that does not require nursing judgment and is appropriate for UAPs.

data.fact: 5 Rights of Delegation: Right Task, Right Circumstance, Right Person, Right Direction/Communication, Right Supervision.
data.alert: The RN is ALWAYS accountable for delegated tasks, even if performed by someone else.
data.q: Who is ultimately accountable for a delegated task?
data.rationale: The RN who delegates retains accountability; delegation transfers the task, not the responsibility.

data.fact: Airway first, then Breathing, then Circulation. Always prioritize in this order.
data.alert: Exception: Hemorrhage (stop bleeding first, then airway). On NCLEX, airway is usually the answer.
data.q: A nurse finds 3 patients need care. Who is seen FIRST?
data.rationale: Airway obstruction is immediately life-threatening; ABC prioritization places airway above all other concerns.

data.fact: Apply Maslow to NCLEX questions: Physiologic needs FIRST (ABCs, food, water, elimination), then Safety, then Psychosocial.
data.alert: Physical needs ALWAYS before emotional needs. Don't choose 'therapeutic communication' over an unstable patient.
data.q: A patient is anxious AND has labored breathing. The nurse should FIRST:
data.rationale: Physiologic needs (breathing) take priority over psychosocial needs (anxiety) per Maslow's hierarchy.

data.fact: New onset/acute problems take priority over chronic/stable conditions.
data.alert: Unstable > Stable. Unexpected > Expected. Acute change > Chronic baseline.
data.q: Which patient should the nurse see FIRST?
a: COPD patient with O2 sat of 89%
Post-op patient with new onset confusion
data.rationale: New onset confusion is an acute change requiring immediate assessment; the others are chronic/expected findings.

data.fact: Assign the most stable, most predictable patients to the least experienced nurse.
data.alert: New grads/floats get stable patients. Charge nurse keeps the most complex/unstable patients.
data.q: Which patient should be assigned to the new graduate nurse?
a: Stable chronic heart failure on telemetry
data.rationale: The stable CHF patient is most predictable; complex/unstable patients require experienced nursing judgment.

data.fact: Chain of Infection: Infectious Agent → Reservoir → Portal of Exit → Mode of Transmission → Portal of Entry → Susceptible Host.
data.alert: Break ANY link in the chain to prevent infection. Hand hygiene is the #1 method.
data.q: The MOST effective way to prevent infection transmission is:
data.rationale: Hand hygiene (washing or alcohol-based rub) is the single most effective measure to break the chain of infection.

data.fact: Standard Precautions = ALL patients, ALL the time. Gloves for body fluids, Mask if splash risk, Gown if soiling risk.
data.alert: Treat ALL blood and body fluids as potentially infectious regardless of diagnosis.
data.q: Standard Precautions apply to which patients?
data.rationale: Standard Precautions are universal — applied to every patient encounter regardless of known or suspected infection status.

data.fact: Airborne: TB, Measles (Rubeola), Varicella (Chickenpox). Private room, negative pressure, N95 respirator.
data.alert: Remember: My Three Viruses = Measles, TB, Varicella. Door must remain CLOSED.
data.q: Which precaution requires an N95 respirator?
data.rationale: Airborne precautions require N95 respirators because particles remain suspended in air and travel long distances.

data.fact: Droplet: Flu, Pertussis, Meningitis, Mumps, Rubella, Strep. Surgical mask within 3 feet.
data.alert: Private room or cohort. No negative pressure needed. Mask on when entering room.
data.q: Droplet precautions require the nurse to wear:
data.rationale: A surgical mask protects against large respiratory droplets that travel up to 3 feet before falling.

data.fact: Contact: MRSA, C. diff, Scabies, Lice, RSV, Herpes Zoster (localized). Gloves + Gown on entry.
data.alert: Dedicated equipment (stethoscope, BP cuff). C. diff: soap and water ONLY (alcohol doesn't kill spores).
data.q: A patient with C. diff requires which hand hygiene method?
data.rationale: C. diff spores are NOT killed by alcohol-based hand rubs; only soap and water with friction removes them.

data.fact: Sterile field: 1-inch border is contaminated. Never turn back on sterile field. Below waist = unsterile.
data.alert: Wet = contaminated. If in doubt, consider it contaminated. Open packages away from you.
data.q: The nurse reaches across a sterile field. The field is now:
a: Only the touched area is contaminated
data.rationale: Reaching across a sterile field breaks the barrier; the entire field is considered contaminated and must be replaced.

data.fact: Physician obtains informed consent (explains procedure, risks, alternatives). Nurse WITNESSES the signature.
data.alert: Patient must be competent, voluntary, informed. Sedated/confused patients CANNOT consent.
data.q: The nurse's role in informed consent is to:
data.rationale: The nurse witnesses that the patient signed voluntarily and appeared to understand; the physician explains the procedure.

data.fact: Restraints = LAST resort. Try alternatives first (reorientation, sitter, bed alarm).
data.alert: Check circulation q15min-2hr. Release q2hr for ROM/toileting/nutrition. Physician order required. Tie to BED FRAME (not side rails).
data.q: How often should restrained extremities be released for ROM?
data.rationale: Restraints must be released every 2 hours for ROM exercises, toileting, nutrition, and circulation checks.

data.alert: Standardized handoff tool. Use when calling the physician or during shift report.
data.q: When calling the physician about a patient change, the nurse should use:
data.rationale: SBAR provides a structured, concise communication framework that ensures critical information is relayed efficiently.

data.fact: Report: falls, med errors, equipment failures, near misses. Fill out incident report immediately.
data.alert: Do NOT document 'incident report filed' in patient chart. Chart only the objective facts. Report is for QI, not punitive.
data.q: After a medication error, the nurse should NOT:
a: Document objective findings in the chart
Write 'incident report filed' in the chart
data.rationale: Never reference the incident report in the patient chart; it is a quality improvement document and is legally discoverable if referenced.

data.fact: See the patient with the most life-threatening, least expected finding first.
data.alert: Stable/expected findings can wait. Think: Who will DIE if I don't see them NOW?
data.q: Which patient should the nurse assess FIRST?
a: Patient 2 days post-op with pain of 4/10
Patient with COPD and SpO2 of 90%
Patient with a new tracheostomy and labored breathing
data.rationale: A new tracheostomy with labored breathing is an acute airway emergency requiring immediate intervention.

data.fact: Document: factually, objectively, timely. Use quotes for patient statements. Never chart in advance.
data.alert: Late entry: write 'Late Entry' with current time. Never use white-out or erase. Draw single line through errors.
data.q: To correct a charting error, the nurse should:
a: Draw a single line through it and initial
Tear out the page and redo it
Leave it and add a sticky note
data.rationale: A single line through the error, initialed and dated, preserves the original entry while indicating the correction.

data.fact: Normal Lab Values: K+ 3.5-5.0, Na+ 136-145, Ca++ 9.0-10.5, Mg++ 1.3-2.1, BUN 10-20, Creatinine 0.7-1.3, Glucose 70-100 (fasting), Hgb 12-18, Hct 37-52%, WBC 5,000-10,000, Platelets 150,000-400,000.
data.alert: Know these cold. Anything outside these ranges requires clinical judgment. Potassium and glucose are the most commonly tested.
data.q: A patient has a serum potassium of 5.8 mEq/L. This value is:
data.rationale: Normal K+ is 3.5-5.0 mEq/L. A value of 5.8 is elevated (hyperkalemia) and requires assessment and possible intervention.

data.fact: ABCD Priority for lab values: A = Abnormal (do nothing extra), B = Be Concerned (assess patient, check order), C = Critical (hold med, call provider, assess), D = Deadly (emergency intervention NOW).
data.alert: Critical K+ (<2.5 or >6.5), glucose <40, Na+ <120 or >160, platelets <20,000 = act immediately. When in doubt, HOLD the med and CALL the provider.
data.q: A patient on digoxin has a K+ of 2.8. Using the ABCD priority system, this is:
a: B - Be concerned, assess the patient
C - Critical, hold digoxin and call provider
data.rationale: K+ of 2.8 is critically low. Low potassium potentiates digoxin toxicity, so hold the digoxin, assess the patient, and notify the provider immediately.

data.fact: When a lab value is critical: 1) HOLD the medication related to that lab. 2) ASSESS the patient for symptoms. 3) PREPARE for possible intervention. 4) CALL the provider with the value and assessment.
data.alert: Never give a med that worsens a critical lab. Example: Do NOT give potassium if K+ is 6.0. Do NOT give insulin if glucose is 55.
data.q: A patient's INR is 4.5 (therapeutic range 2-3). The nurse should FIRST:
a: Hold the warfarin and notify the provider
data.rationale: An INR of 4.5 is supratherapeutic. The nurse should hold the warfarin (the causative med) and notify the provider for further orders before taking additional action.

data.fact: LPN can: give PO/IM/SQ meds, perform wound care, reinforce teaching, collect data, perform sterile dressing changes, suction (stable trach), do VS.
data.alert: LPN CANNOT: do initial assessment, create care plans, give IV push meds, hang blood, hang first-time IV meds, triage, take telephone orders in most states, teach new content, or manage unstable patients.
data.q: Which task can the RN delegate to the LPN?
a: Developing the care plan for a new admission
Administering an oral medication to a stable patient
Hanging the first unit of packed RBCs
Performing initial triage in the ED
data.rationale: LPNs can administer oral medications to stable patients. Care planning, blood administration, and triage require RN-level assessment and judgment.

data.fact: UAP/CNA can: take vital signs, bathe/feed/ambulate patients, measure I&O, perform CPR, empty drains (Foley, Hemovac, JP), transport, apply anti-embolism stockings.
data.alert: UAP CANNOT: assess, chart clinical findings, administer ANY meds (except topical OTC in some states), perform sterile procedures, take phone orders, or give report to oncoming shift.
data.q: Which task is appropriate to delegate to the UAP?
a: Assess the patient after a fall
Evaluate the effectiveness of pain medication
data.rationale: Measuring and recording I&O is within UAP scope. Assessment, medication administration, and evaluation of treatment are RN responsibilities.

data.fact: Chain of command for staff issues: Step 1 — Talk to the person DIRECTLY first. Step 2 — If behavior continues or is dangerous, report to the charge nurse/supervisor.
data.alert: Never ignore unsafe practice. Impaired colleague (drugs/alcohol) — report to supervisor immediately, do NOT confront alone. New graduates get STABLE patients only.
data.q: A nurse smells alcohol on a coworker's breath. The FIRST action is:
a: Report to the charge nurse/supervisor immediately
Document the observation in the chart
Ignore it unless patient care is affected
data.rationale: An impaired coworker is a safety emergency. Report to the supervisor immediately. Do not confront alone or wait to see if care is affected.

data.fact: Assign stable patients to new graduates: stable, predictable, non-complex. Chronic conditions with expected findings are ideal.
data.alert: Never assign: fresh post-ops, chest tubes, unstable vitals, drips requiring titration, or patients at risk for rapid decompensation to a new grad.
data.q: Which patient is most appropriate to assign to a new graduate nurse?
a: Patient returning from CABG surgery 2 hours ago
Patient with COPD and stable SpO2 on 2L O2
Patient with chest tubes after a pneumothorax
Patient on a heparin drip requiring titration
data.rationale: A COPD patient with stable oxygen saturation on a consistent flow rate is predictable and appropriate for a new graduate. The others require experienced assessment skills.

data.fact: Donning (putting on) PPE sequence: 1) Hand hygiene, 2) Gown, 3) Mask/Respirator, 4) Goggles/Face shield, 5) Gloves (LAST — go over gown cuffs).
data.alert: Gloves go on LAST and must cover the gown cuffs. Mask must be fitted before entering the room. N95 requires fit testing for airborne precautions.
data.q: When donning PPE, which item does the nurse put on LAST?
data.rationale: Gloves are applied last during donning so they can cover the gown cuffs, creating a continuous barrier. The sequence is gown, mask, goggles, then gloves.

data.fact: Doffing (removing) PPE sequence: 1) Gloves (FIRST — most contaminated), 2) Hand hygiene, 3) Goggles/Face shield, 4) Gown, 5) Hand hygiene, 6) Mask/Respirator (LAST — remove OUTSIDE room).
data.alert: Gloves come off FIRST because they are most contaminated. Mask comes off LAST, outside the room. Hand hygiene between EVERY step.
data.q: When removing PPE, which item is removed FIRST?
data.rationale: Gloves are the most contaminated PPE item and are removed first. This prevents cross-contamination when removing subsequent items.

data.fact: 3 precaution types: 1) Contact (MRSA, C. diff, scabies) — gown + gloves. 2) Droplet (flu, meningitis, pertussis) — surgical mask within 3 ft. 3) Airborne (TB, measles, varicella, COVID) — N95 + negative pressure room.
data.alert: Private room for ALL transmission-based precautions. Airborne REQUIRES negative pressure. "My Chicken Hez TB" = Measles, Chickenpox, Herpes zoster (disseminated), TB = AIRBORNE.
data.q: A patient is diagnosed with active tuberculosis. Which precaution is required?
a: Contact precautions with gown and gloves
Airborne precautions with N95 and negative pressure room
data.rationale: TB is transmitted via airborne nuclei and requires an N95 respirator and negative pressure (airborne infection isolation) room.

data.fact: 5 auscultation sites (mnemonic: APE To Man): Aortic = 2nd R ICS, Pulmonic = 2nd L ICS, Erb's Point = 3rd L ICS, Tricuspid = 4th L ICS, Mitral = 5th L ICS midclavicular.
data.alert: Auscultate with diaphragm for high-pitched sounds (S1, S2, murmurs). Bell for low-pitched (S3, S4). S3 = heart failure. S4 = stiff ventricle.
data.q: The nurse auscultates the mitral valve at which location?
data.rationale: The mitral valve (apex) is auscultated at the 5th left intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Remember APE To Man for the sequence.

data.fact: 9 major pulse locations: Temporal, Carotid, Apical (5th ICS MCL), Brachial (antecubital), Radial (most common), Femoral (inguinal), Popliteal (behind knee), Dorsalis Pedis (top of foot), Posterior Tibial (behind medial malleolus).
data.alert: Apical pulse: count for FULL 60 seconds (esp. before digoxin). Doppler if pulse not palpable. Check pedal pulses post-cardiac cath and for PVD.
data.q: Before administering digoxin, the nurse should assess which pulse for a full 60 seconds?
data.rationale: The apical pulse is counted for a full 60 seconds before giving digoxin. Hold if below 60 bpm in adults or below 100 bpm in infants.

data.fact: The Breaker Rule: When two answer choices seem equally correct, find the ORGAN in the modifying phrase of each option. The option whose organ is more vital wins.
data.alert: Brain > Heart > Lungs > Liver > Kidneys. If stuck between two answers, the one referencing the most vital organ system takes priority.
data.q: Two patients need the nurse: one with new-onset confusion and one with new crackles in the lungs. Using the Breaker Rule, see FIRST:
data.rationale: Brain outranks lungs in the organ hierarchy. New-onset confusion could indicate stroke, ICP changes, or hypoxia — all life-threatening.

data.fact: For therapeutic communication questions: 1) Acknowledge the feeling, 2) Explore the feeling, 3) Never give advice/false reassurance, 4) Reflect back what the patient said.
data.alert: WRONG responses: "Don't worry," "Everything will be fine," "I know how you feel," "Why did you do that?" RIGHT: "Tell me more about how you're feeling."
data.q: A patient says, "I don't think I'm going to make it." The BEST nurse response is:
a: "Tell me more about what you're feeling right now."
data.rationale: Acknowledging and exploring feelings is therapeutic. "Tell me more" is open-ended and reflective. Avoid false reassurance, "why" questions, and deflecting to others.

data.fact: Select All That Apply questions: Treat EACH option as a True/False question independently. Do NOT look for patterns. Each option stands alone — include it if TRUE, exclude if FALSE.
data.alert: The "Umbrella strategy" for regular questions: pick the answer that COVERS all the others without saying a specific thing. Use safe, general, broad options.
data.q: The best strategy for NCLEX Select All That Apply questions is:
a: Look for a pattern in the correct answers
Evaluate each option independently as true or false
data.rationale: Each SATA option should be evaluated independently as true or false. There is no pattern or set number of correct answers.

gero.title: Gerontology
gero.description: Aging changes, polypharmacy, dementia, fall prevention

data.fact: Decreased cardiac output, increased peripheral vascular resistance, stiffening of blood vessels, orthostatic hypotension.
data.alert: Rise slowly from lying to sitting to standing. Allow time to equilibrate before ambulating.
data.q: An age-related cardiovascular change in the elderly is:
data.rationale: Aging causes vessel stiffening and baroreceptor sensitivity loss, leading to orthostatic hypotension and fall risk.

data.fact: Decreased lung elasticity, reduced vital capacity, weaker cough reflex, increased residual volume.
data.alert: Higher risk for pneumonia and atelectasis. Encourage deep breathing, incentive spirometry, flu/pneumonia vaccines.
data.q: Which respiratory change occurs with aging?
data.rationale: Aging reduces lung elasticity and chest wall compliance, decreasing vital capacity and weakening the cough reflex.

data.fact: Decreased GFR and renal blood flow. Reduced ability to concentrate urine. Nocturia common.
data.alert: Drug clearance is slower — adjust doses! Creatinine may be falsely normal (less muscle mass producing it).
data.q: Why must medication doses often be reduced in the elderly?
data.rationale: Decreased GFR means drugs are cleared more slowly, increasing the risk of toxicity at standard adult doses.

data.fact: Decreased motility, reduced gastric acid secretion, slower peristalsis, decreased liver metabolism.
data.alert: Constipation is common. Encourage fluids, fiber, activity. Aspiration risk increases (weaker gag reflex).
data.q: A common GI complaint in the elderly is:
data.rationale: Decreased GI motility and peristalsis with aging leads to constipation; fluids, fiber, and activity help prevent it.

data.fact: Presbyopia (farsightedness), Presbycusis (hearing loss, especially high-pitched sounds). Decreased taste/smell.
data.alert: Speak in low tones (not louder). Use large print. Good lighting. Reduce fall risk from impaired vision.
data.q: When communicating with an elderly patient with hearing loss, the nurse should:
data.rationale: Age-related hearing loss (presbycusis) affects high-frequency sounds first; speaking in lower tones is more effective than shouting.

data.fact: Decreased bone density (osteoporosis risk), loss of muscle mass (sarcopenia), reduced flexibility, joint stiffness.
data.alert: Weight-bearing exercise, calcium + Vitamin D, fall prevention are critical.
data.q: The primary musculoskeletal concern in aging females is:
data.rationale: Postmenopausal women lose estrogen protection, accelerating bone density loss and increasing osteoporosis and fracture risk.

data.fact: Thinning epidermis, decreased subcutaneous fat, reduced elasticity, slower wound healing, less sweat production.
data.alert: Higher risk for skin tears, pressure ulcers, hypothermia, and dehydration. Assess skin frequently.
data.q: An elderly patient is at increased risk for skin tears because of:
data.rationale: Aging thins the epidermis and reduces subcutaneous fat, making skin fragile and prone to tears with minimal friction.

data.fact:
Delirium = ACUTE onset, reversible, fluctuating LOC, often caused by infection/meds/metabolic.
Dementia = GRADUAL onset, irreversible, progressive cognitive decline.
data.alert: New confusion in elderly = DELIRIUM until proven otherwise. Check for UTI, meds, dehydration, hypoxia FIRST.
data.q: A previously oriented elderly patient suddenly becomes confused. This most likely indicates:
data.rationale: Acute onset confusion is delirium (reversible) — look for treatable causes like UTI, medications, or metabolic imbalance.

data.fact: Increased confusion and agitation in late afternoon/evening in patients with dementia.
data.alert: Interventions: structured routine, adequate lighting, reduce stimulation in PM, avoid caffeine after noon.
data.q: A patient with dementia becomes agitated every evening at 5 PM. This is called:
data.rationale: Sundowning is increased confusion/agitation in late day, common in dementia; maintaining routine and lighting helps manage it.

data.fact: Polypharmacy = use of multiple medications (typically 5+). Leading cause of adverse drug events in elderly.
data.alert: Review ALL meds (including OTC/herbs) at every visit. Simplify regimens. Watch for drug-drug interactions.
data.q: The greatest risk of polypharmacy in the elderly is:
data.rationale: Multiple medications increase the risk of dangerous drug-drug interactions, side effects, and medication errors.

data.fact: Beers List = medications potentially inappropriate for elderly. Includes: benzodiazepines, anticholinergics, NSAIDs (long-term), muscle relaxants.
data.alert: Diphenhydramine (Benadryl) = highly anticholinergic — avoid in elderly (confusion, urinary retention, constipation, dry mouth).
data.q: Which medication class should generally be AVOIDED in the elderly?
data.rationale: Benzodiazepines are on the Beers List because they increase fall risk, sedation, confusion, and cognitive impairment in the elderly.

data.fact: Falls = #1 cause of injury death in adults over 65. Risk: meds, vision, gait, environment, orthostatic hypotension.
data.alert: Home safety: remove rugs, install grab bars, nightlights, non-slip mats. In hospital: bed alarm, call light in reach, low bed.
data.q: The leading cause of injury-related death in adults over 65 is:
data.rationale: Falls are the number one cause of injury and injury-related death in the elderly; prevention is a nursing priority.

data.fact: Types: Physical, Emotional, Financial, Neglect, Sexual. Look for unexplained bruises, withdrawal, malnutrition, poor hygiene.
data.alert: Mandatory reporting in all states. Interview patient ALONE (away from caregiver). Document objectively.
data.q: When assessing for elder abuse, the nurse should:
a: Interview patient with the caregiver present
Only report if patient requests it
Wait for the physician to assess
data.rationale: The patient must be interviewed privately to allow honest disclosure; the presence of the abuser prevents truthful answers.

data.fact: Elderly have impaired thermoregulation. Decreased shivering, less subcutaneous fat, reduced sweating.
data.alert: Hypothermia risk even at room temperature. Hyperthermia risk in hot weather (may not feel thirsty). Monitor temp closely.
data.q: An elderly patient is at increased risk for hypothermia because of:
a: Decreased ability to shiver and less subcutaneous fat
data.rationale: Aging reduces shivering response, subcutaneous insulation, and metabolic heat production, increasing hypothermia risk.

data.fact: Often presents atypically: somatic complaints (pain, fatigue, GI issues) rather than sadness. Often underdiagnosed.
data.alert: Screen with Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS). Depression is NOT a normal part of aging. Assess for suicide risk.
data.q: Depression in the elderly most commonly presents as:
a: Somatic complaints like pain and fatigue
data.rationale: Elderly patients often express depression through physical complaints rather than emotional symptoms, making it harder to diagnose.

data.fact: Types: Stress (cough/sneeze leak), Urge (overactive bladder), Overflow (incomplete emptying), Functional (can't get to toilet in time).
data.alert: NOT a normal part of aging. Kegel exercises for stress incontinence. Timed voiding schedules help.
data.q: Urinary incontinence in the elderly is:
a: Not normal and should be evaluated
data.rationale: Incontinence is NOT a normal aging change; it has treatable causes and should always be evaluated and managed.

data.fact: Decreased caloric needs but SAME or INCREASED protein, calcium, Vitamin D, B12 needs.
data.alert: Risk for malnutrition: decreased taste/smell, dental problems, isolation, depression, poverty. Monitor albumin/prealbumin.
data.q: Nutritional needs that INCREASE with aging include:
data.rationale: While caloric needs decrease, calcium and Vitamin D requirements increase to prevent osteoporosis and fractures.

data.fact:
Living Will = written wishes for end-of-life care.
Durable Power of Attorney = designates someone to make healthcare decisions if patient cannot.
data.alert: Discuss BEFORE a crisis. Must be competent when signing. Can be revoked at any time. Nurse is a witness, not advisor.
data.q: A Durable Power of Attorney for Healthcare allows:
a: The physician to make all decisions
A designated person to make decisions if the patient cannot
The hospital to override patient wishes
data.rationale: The DPOA designates a trusted person to make healthcare decisions only when the patient is unable to do so themselves.

data.fact: Decreased immune response. Reduced T-cell function. Blunted febrile response to infection.
data.alert: Elderly may NOT develop a fever with infection — monitor for subtle signs: confusion, falls, decreased appetite, lethargy.
data.q: An elderly patient with pneumonia may NOT show which typical sign?
data.rationale: The aging immune system produces a blunted febrile response; elderly patients may be afebrile even with serious infections.

data.fact: Decreased REM and deep sleep. More frequent awakenings. Takes longer to fall asleep. Earlier bedtime/wake time.
data.alert: Avoid sedatives/hypnotics (Beers List). Non-pharm interventions: consistent schedule, warm milk, reduce caffeine, quiet environment.
data.q: A normal sleep change in the elderly includes:
data.rationale: Aging reduces deep sleep (stages 3-4) and REM sleep, causing lighter sleep with more frequent awakenings — this is normal.

data.alert: 80% of people over 70 have at least one chronic condition. ADL ability is a more accurate measure than chronologic age.
data.q: A 78-year-old patient is classified as:
data.rationale: Middle-old is defined as ages 75-84; young-old is 65-74; old-old is 85 and over.

data.fact: Erikson's 8th stage: Integrity vs Despair. Older adults reflect on life — acceptance = integrity; regret = despair.
data.alert: The major task of old age is to redefine self in relation to a changed role. Reminiscence therapy supports integrity.
data.q: According to Erikson, the developmental task of older adults is:
data.rationale: Erikson's 8th and final stage involves reflecting on life with a sense of fulfillment (integrity) or regret (despair).

data.fact:
Activity Theory: Stay active to age well.
Disengagement Theory: Gradual social withdrawal is normal.
Wear-and-Tear: Cells damaged by free radicals over time.
data.alert: Activity theory is most supported — maintaining involvement promotes life satisfaction and self-esteem.
data.q: Which aging theory states that staying active promotes successful aging?
data.rationale: Activity theory holds that continued social and physical engagement is essential for life satisfaction in older adults.

data.fact: Elderly often present WITHOUT classic signs. MI may lack chest pain. Infection may lack fever. UTI presents as confusion.
data.alert: Diseases are subtle, slow to develop, and different from younger adults. Always investigate new confusion!
data.q: An elderly patient with a UTI is most likely to present with:
data.rationale: UTIs in the elderly often present atypically with confusion, falls, or lethargy rather than classic urinary symptoms.

data.fact: Angina in older adults may be absent or present as GI symptoms (indigestion, nausea). Dyspnea may be the only sign.
data.alert: Do NOT assume GI complaints in elderly are just dietary — rule out cardiac causes. Confusion can also indicate oxygen deficit.
data.q: An elderly patient experiencing an MI may present with:
data.rationale: Elderly patients often have atypical MI presentations including indigestion, nausea, dyspnea, or confusion instead of classic chest pain.

data.fact: Bladder capacity decreases by half. Weakened muscles cause frequency, nocturia, and residual urine → UTI risk.
data.alert: BPH causes urinary retention in men. Caffeine worsens incontinence (inhibits ADH). Avoid sedatives at night (nocturnal incontinence).
data.q: Bladder capacity in the elderly decreases by approximately:
data.rationale: Bladder capacity decreases by about half with aging, leading to urinary frequency, nocturia, and increased UTI risk from residual urine.

data.fact: Menopause: Ovarian function decreases, estrogen declines. Vaginal mucosa becomes dry and alkaline → dyspareunia (painful intercourse).
data.alert: Breast tissue involutes. Perineal muscles weaken (stress incontinence). Libido may or may not decline.
data.q: Vaginal dryness in postmenopausal women is caused by:
data.rationale: Estrogen decline after menopause causes vaginal mucosa to thin, dry out, and become alkaline, leading to dyspareunia.

data.fact: Andropause: Gradual testosterone decline. Prostate enlargement (BPH). Erections less firm, shorter duration.
data.alert: Sexual function is maintained with aging — nurses should assess sexuality in ALL settings. Annual DRE for prostate screening.
data.q: The term for age-related testosterone decline in men is:
data.rationale: Andropause refers to the gradual decline in testosterone in aging males, causing changes in sexual function and prostate enlargement.

data.fact: Cataracts = progressive clouding/opacity of the lens. Most common pathologic eye problem in older adults.
data.alert: Treatment is surgical removal. Post-op: avoid bending, straining, coughing. Affected eye may be patched — risk for disorientation.
data.q: The most common pathologic eye condition in older adults is:
data.rationale: Cataracts are the most common age-related eye problem; progressive lens clouding impairs vision and is corrected surgically.

data.fact: Glaucoma: Increased IOP → optic nerve damage. Risk increases with age. Macular Degeneration: Principal cause of blindness.
data.alert: Glaucoma: IOP measured by tonometry. Macular degeneration: central vision lost first. Both require annual eye exams.
data.q: The principal cause of blindness in older adults is:
data.rationale: Macular degeneration is the leading cause of irreversible blindness in older adults, affecting central vision first.

data.fact: The 4 A's of Alzheimer's: Agnosia (can't recognize), Amnesia (memory loss), Apraxia (can't perform tasks), Aphasia (can't communicate).
data.alert: Most common brain disorder and leading cause of death in older adults. Beta amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles found in brain.
data.q: The 4 A's of Alzheimer's disease include all EXCEPT:
data.rationale: The 4 A's are Agnosia, Amnesia, Apraxia, and Aphasia — not Anemia, which is a blood disorder unrelated to Alzheimer's.

data.fact:
Alzheimer's: Most common, amyloid plaques.
Vascular: From ischemic brain lesions (HTN, hyperlipidemia).
Lewy Body: Microscopic deposits.
Frontotemporal (Pick's): Frontal/temporal lobe degeneration.
data.alert: Conditions that mimic dementia: UTI, dehydration, electrolyte imbalance, medication effects, metabolic disorders — always rule these out!
data.q: Vascular dementia develops as a result of:
data.rationale: Vascular dementia results from ischemic brain damage caused by hypertension, hyperlipidemia, smoking, or obesity.

data.fact:
Acetylcholinesterase Inhibitors: Donepezil (Aricept), Rivastigmine, Galantamine — for early to moderate stage.
Memantine (NMDA antagonist) — for moderate to severe.
data.alert: SE: GI distress, elevated liver enzymes. Take with meals. Do NOT discontinue abruptly. No anticholinergic meds with these drugs.
data.q: Which medication class is used for early-stage Alzheimer's?
data.rationale: Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (Donepezil, Rivastigmine, Galantamine) increase acetylcholine availability for early-moderate Alzheimer's.

data.fact: Use low-pitched tones (not louder). Face the patient. Give time to respond. Use simple, short questions. Avoid jargon.
data.alert: Reminiscence validates the older person. Use touch therapeutically (ask permission first). Address with respect (Mr./Mrs.).
data.q: When communicating with an older adult, the nurse should:
a: Give adequate time to respond and face the patient
data.rationale: Older adults need more processing time; facing them, speaking clearly in low tones, and allowing time to respond shows respect and aids comprehension.

data.fact: Elderly experience multiple compounded losses: health, independence, spouse, friends, income, home, roles.
data.alert: Grief is individual and culturally influenced. Complicated grief = no progression through mourning. Screen for depression and suicide risk.
data.q: Multiple losses in the elderly can lead to:
data.rationale: Compounded losses overwhelm coping ability, leading to bereavement overload, depression, substance abuse, and suicide risk.

data.fact: Hospice = comfort care for terminal illness (prognosis ~6 months). Focus: symptom management, NOT cure.
data.alert: Pain management is the PRIORITY. Death rattle (gurgling) is distressing for families — provide support. Assess for depression and delirium.
data.q: The priority in end-of-life care is:
data.rationale: End-of-life care prioritizes pain management and comfort; untreated pain affects quality of life, sleep, and dignity.

data.fact: Recommended: ECG, chest X-ray, PFTs, tonometry (IOP/glaucoma), blood glucose, Pap/DRE, mammogram, bone density, cholesterol.
data.alert: Screen for: depression, cognitive impairment, substance abuse, elder abuse, obesity, BP, hearing/vision. Encourage flu/pneumonia/shingles vaccines.
data.q: Which screening is specifically important for detecting glaucoma?
data.rationale: Tonometry measures intraocular pressure (IOP) and is essential for early detection of glaucoma, which increases with age.

data.fact: Hypothyroidism often misdiagnosed as "normal aging" in elderly. Insulin production decreases → Type 2 DM common.
data.alert: Most common endocrine disorders: thyroid dysfunction and Type 2 DM. Encourage thyroid testing in depressed elderly — hypothyroidism mimics depression.
data.q: Hypothyroidism in the elderly is often mistaken for:
data.rationale: Hypothyroidism symptoms (fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, cognitive slowing) overlap with normal aging, delaying diagnosis.

data.fact: Neurons decrease and do not regenerate. Central processing slows. Proprioception declines → balance problems.
data.alert: Intelligence remains constant! Performance is slower but accuracy is maintained. Loss of vibratory sense in lower extremities is common.
data.q: Which statement about neurologic aging is TRUE?
a: Intelligence remains constant but processing slows
data.rationale: Intelligence remains intact in healthy older adults; however, central processing speed decreases and reaction time is slower.

data.fact: Dysrhythmias increase with age due to higher systolic BP and enlarged atria. Can cause syncope, falls, TIAs, confusion.
data.alert: More dangerous in elderly — decreased cardiac output is poorly tolerated. Diastolic murmurs in >50% of older adults (valves thicken).
data.q: Dysrhythmias in older adults are particularly dangerous because:
a: Older adults cannot tolerate decreased cardiac output
data.rationale: Elderly patients have less cardiac reserve; dysrhythmias that decrease cardiac output can cause syncope, falls, TIAs, and confusion.

nutr.title: Nutrition
nutr.description: Vitamins, minerals, therapeutic diets, nutritional support

data.alert: Alcohol = 7 cal/g but provides NO nutrition.
data.q: How many calories per gram does fat provide?
data.rationale: Fat is the most calorie-dense macronutrient at 9 calories per gram.

data.fact: Complete proteins contain all 9 essential amino acids (meat, fish, eggs, dairy, soy). Incomplete proteins lack one or more (beans, grains, nuts).
data.alert: Combine incomplete proteins (rice + beans) to form complete proteins.
data.q: Which food is a complete protein source?
data.rationale: Eggs contain all 9 essential amino acids and are considered a complete protein.

data.fact: Vitamins A, D, E, K are fat-soluble (stored in liver and fatty tissue). Require dietary fat for absorption.
data.alert: Toxicity risk with excess intake because they accumulate in the body.
data.q: Which vitamin is NOT fat-soluble?
data.rationale: Vitamin C is water-soluble. Fat-soluble vitamins are A, D, E, and K (remember: ADEK).

data.fact: B-complex and Vitamin C are water-soluble. Not stored in body — need daily intake. Excreted by kidneys.
data.alert: Deficiency develops faster than fat-soluble vitamins since they are not stored.
data.q: Water-soluble vitamins are excreted by which organ?
data.rationale: Water-soluble vitamins are filtered and excreted by the kidneys in urine.

data.fact: Vitamin A: essential for vision, immune function, and skin integrity. Sources: liver, carrots, sweet potatoes, spinach.
data.alert: Deficiency = Night blindness. Toxicity = Liver damage, birth defects.
data.q: A deficiency of Vitamin A causes which condition?
data.rationale: Vitamin A is critical for rhodopsin production in the retina; deficiency leads to night blindness.

data.fact: Vitamin D promotes calcium absorption from the gut. Sources: sunlight, fortified milk, fatty fish. Calcium sources: dairy, leafy greens, fortified foods.
data.alert: Deficiency: Rickets (children), Osteomalacia (adults). Calcium deficiency = Osteoporosis.
data.q: Vitamin D deficiency in children causes which condition?
data.rationale: Rickets is caused by Vitamin D deficiency in children, leading to soft and deformed bones.

data.fact: Vitamin K is essential for synthesis of clotting factors (II, VII, IX, X). Sources: dark leafy greens (kale, spinach, broccoli).
data.alert: Newborns receive Vitamin K injection at birth. Interacts with Warfarin!
data.q: A patient on Warfarin should be cautious with which food?
data.rationale: Kale is high in Vitamin K which antagonizes Warfarin's anticoagulant effect.

data.fact: Iron: needed for hemoglobin synthesis. Heme iron (meat, best absorbed) vs Non-heme iron (plants, beans). Vitamin C enhances absorption.
data.alert: Take iron with Vitamin C (orange juice). Avoid with dairy, antacids, or coffee.
data.q: Which enhances iron absorption?
data.rationale: Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) converts ferric iron to ferrous iron, enhancing absorption in the gut.

data.fact: Potassium (normal 3.5-5.0 mEq/L): critical for cardiac function and muscle contraction. Sources: bananas, oranges, potatoes, spinach.
data.alert: Hypokalemia: muscle weakness, dysrhythmias, U waves. Hyperkalemia: tall peaked T waves, cardiac arrest.
data.q: Which food is highest in potassium?
data.rationale: Bananas are one of the most well-known high-potassium foods at ~422 mg per medium banana.

data.fact: Sodium (normal 135-145 mEq/L): regulates fluid balance and nerve impulses. Major dietary source: processed/canned foods, table salt.
data.alert: Hyponatremia: confusion, seizures. Hypernatremia: thirst, dry mucous membranes, restlessness.
data.q: A patient with heart failure should follow which diet?
data.rationale: Heart failure patients need sodium restriction (typically 2g/day) to prevent fluid retention and edema.

data.fact: Renal diet: restrict potassium, phosphorus, sodium, and fluid. Protein may be restricted pre-dialysis but increased during dialysis.
data.alert: Avoid: bananas, oranges, tomatoes, dairy, chocolate, nuts, cola.
data.q: A patient on hemodialysis needs which dietary modification?
data.rationale: Dialysis patients need increased protein to replace losses during dialysis treatments.

data.fact: Cardiac diet: low sodium (<2g/day), low saturated fat, low cholesterol. Emphasize fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean proteins.
data.alert: DASH diet: high in fruits, vegetables, low-fat dairy; proven to reduce BP.
data.q: The DASH diet is recommended for which condition?
data.rationale: DASH (Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension) is specifically designed to lower blood pressure.

data.fact: Diabetic diet: consistent carbohydrate intake, glycemic index awareness, balanced meals. Count carbs (typically 45-60g per meal).
data.alert: Carbohydrates have the greatest impact on blood glucose levels.
data.q: Which macronutrient most affects blood glucose?
data.rationale: Carbohydrates are broken down into glucose and have the most direct impact on blood sugar levels.

data.fact: BMI = weight(kg) / height(m)². Underweight: <18.5. Normal: 18.5-24.9. Overweight: 25-29.9. Obese: ≥30.
data.alert: BMI alone does not account for muscle mass, age, or body composition.
data.q: A BMI of 27 falls into which category?
data.rationale: A BMI of 25-29.9 is classified as overweight.

data.fact: Enteral nutrition: delivered directly to GI tract via NG, NJ, G-tube, or J-tube. Verify placement before feeding (pH <5, X-ray gold standard).
data.alert: Elevate HOB 30-45° during and 30-60 min after feeding to prevent aspiration.
data.q: Before administering a tube feeding, the nurse should FIRST:
data.rationale: Verifying tube placement is the priority safety measure before any tube feeding to prevent aspiration.

data.fact: TPN (Total Parenteral Nutrition): IV nutrition via central line. Contains dextrose, amino acids, lipids, electrolytes, vitamins.
data.alert: Monitor blood glucose q4-6h (high dextrose content). Never abruptly stop TPN — taper to prevent hypoglycemia.
data.q: TPN is administered via which route?
data.rationale: TPN is hypertonic and must be administered through a central venous line to prevent vein damage.

data.fact: Dysphagia: difficulty swallowing. Diet progresses from pureed → mechanical soft → soft → regular. Thickened liquids used to prevent aspiration.
data.alert: Sit upright 90° during meals. Chin-tuck technique. Avoid thin liquids and straws.
data.q: A patient with dysphagia should avoid which item?
data.rationale: Thin liquids are the most aspiration-prone consistency for patients with dysphagia.

data.fact: Soluble fiber (oats, beans): lowers cholesterol, slows glucose absorption. Insoluble fiber (whole wheat, vegetables): promotes bowel regularity.
data.alert: Increase fiber gradually with adequate fluids to prevent constipation and gas.
data.q: Soluble fiber has which primary benefit?
data.rationale: Soluble fiber forms a gel that binds bile acids and helps lower serum cholesterol levels.

data.fact: Signs of malnutrition: unintentional weight loss >10% in 6 months, BMI <18.5, low albumin (<3.5 g/dL), low prealbumin (<16 mg/dL).
data.alert: Prealbumin is a better short-term indicator (half-life 2-3 days) than albumin (half-life 20 days).
data.q: Which lab is the BEST short-term indicator of nutritional status?
data.rationale: Prealbumin has a half-life of 2-3 days, making it the most sensitive short-term marker of nutritional status.

data.fact: Pregnancy: increase calories by ~300/day in 2nd/3rd trimester. Key nutrients: folic acid (prevents neural tube defects), iron, calcium, DHA.
data.alert: Folic acid 400-800 mcg daily BEFORE conception and through 1st trimester is critical.
data.q: Which nutrient prevents neural tube defects?
data.rationale: Folic acid is essential for neural tube closure in the first 28 days of development.

data.fact: Neutropenic diet: avoid raw fruits/vegetables, raw meat, unpasteurized products. Cook all foods thoroughly.
data.alert: Immunocompromised patients (chemo, transplant) need strict food safety precautions.
data.q: A neutropenic patient should avoid which food?
data.rationale: Fresh raw salads carry bacteria risk; neutropenic patients should eat only cooked or processed fruits and vegetables.

data.fact: Wound healing requires increased protein (1.25-1.5 g/kg/day), Vitamin C (collagen synthesis), and zinc.
data.alert: Assess albumin and prealbumin to monitor nutritional support for healing.
data.q: Which nutrient is essential for collagen formation in wound healing?
data.rationale: Vitamin C is a cofactor for collagen synthesis, which is essential for wound healing and tissue repair.

data.fact: Magnesium (normal 1.5-2.5 mEq/L): needed for muscle/nerve function, blood glucose control. Sources: nuts, seeds, spinach, whole grains.
data.alert: Hypomagnesemia often accompanies hypokalemia. Correct Mg first, then K.
data.q: When hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia coexist, the nurse should correct which first?
data.rationale: Magnesium must be corrected first because hypomagnesemia prevents potassium from being retained by the kidneys.

data.fact: Phosphorus (normal 2.5-4.5 mg/dL): inverse relationship with calcium. Sources: dairy, meat, nuts, cola.
data.alert: Hyperphosphatemia in renal failure → give phosphate binders (calcium acetate) with meals.
data.q: Phosphorus has an inverse relationship with which electrolyte?
data.rationale: Phosphorus and calcium have an inverse relationship: when one rises, the other falls.

data.fact: Vitamin B12: needed for RBC production and myelin synthesis. Sources: meat, fish, dairy, eggs. Absorbed with intrinsic factor in ileum.
data.alert: Pernicious anemia = lack of intrinsic factor. Requires lifelong B12 injections.
data.q: Pernicious anemia results from a deficiency of:
data.rationale: Pernicious anemia is caused by lack of intrinsic factor, which is needed for B12 absorption in the terminal ileum.

data.fact: Celiac disease: autoimmune reaction to gluten. Strict lifelong gluten-free diet. Avoid wheat, barley, rye, and contaminated oats.
data.alert: Safe grains: rice, corn, quinoa, buckwheat. Read all food labels carefully.
data.q: A patient with celiac disease must avoid which grain?
data.rationale: Barley contains gluten, which triggers the autoimmune response in celiac disease.

data.fact: 0-6 mo: breast milk or formula only. 6 mo: introduce single-grain cereal (rice). 12 mo: whole milk. No honey until age 1 (botulism risk).
data.alert: Introduce one new food at a time, wait 3-5 days to watch for allergies.
data.q: At what age can a child begin drinking whole cow's milk?
data.rationale: Whole cow's milk is introduced at 12 months; before that, breast milk or formula provides optimal nutrition.

data.fact: Daily fluid needs: ~2-3 L/day for adults. Intake includes oral fluids, IV, and water in foods. Output includes urine (~30 mL/hr minimum), stool, insensible losses.
data.alert: Minimum urine output: 30 mL/hr (adults), 1 mL/kg/hr (pediatrics).
data.q: The minimum acceptable urine output for an adult is:
data.rationale: A minimum urine output of 30 mL/hr (or 0.5 mL/kg/hr) indicates adequate renal perfusion in adults.

data.fact: NPO (nothing by mouth): typically 6-8 hours before surgery for solids, 2 hours for clear liquids. Prevents aspiration during anesthesia.
data.alert: Provide mouth care for NPO patients. Resume diet as ordered post-procedure.
data.q: A patient scheduled for surgery at 0800 should stop eating solids by:
data.rationale: Standard NPO guidelines require stopping solid foods 6-8 hours before surgery; midnight is the traditional cutoff for an 0800 surgery.

data.fact: Vitamin E: antioxidant that protects cell membranes. Sources: nuts, seeds, vegetable oils, spinach.
data.alert: High doses can increase bleeding risk, especially with anticoagulants.
data.q: Which is the primary function of Vitamin E?
data.rationale: Vitamin E is a fat-soluble antioxidant that protects cell membranes from oxidative damage by free radicals.
